**Jerusalem** ^[\[note 2\]](#cite_note-8)^ is a city in the [Southern Levant](/wiki/Southern_Levant "Southern Levant"), on a plateau in the [Judaean Mountains](/wiki/Judaean_Mountains "Judaean Mountains") between the [Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") and the [Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea"). It is one of the [oldest cities in the world](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities"), and is considered [holy](/wiki/Holy_city "Holy city") to the three major [Abrahamic religions](/wiki/Abrahamic_religions "Abrahamic religions")---[Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), and [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam"). Both the [State of Israel](/wiki/State_of_Israel "State of Israel") and the [State of Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine") claim Jerusalem as their [capital city](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city"). Israel maintains its primary governmental institutions there, and the State of Palestine ultimately foresees it as its seat of power. Neither claim is widely [recognized internationally](/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem "Status of Jerusalem").^[\[note 3\]](#cite_note-9)^^[\[7\]](#cite_note-10)^{#cite_ref-10}

Throughout [its long history](/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem "History of Jerusalem"), Jerusalem has been destroyed at least twice, [besieged 23 times](/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(disambiguation) "Siege of Jerusalem (disambiguation)"), captured and recaptured 44 times, and attacked 52 times.^[\[8\]](#cite_note-Moment-11)^ The part of Jerusalem called the [City of David](/wiki/City_of_David_(historic) "City of David (historic)") shows first signs of settlement in the 4th millennium BCE, in the shape of encampments of nomadic shepherds.^[\[9\]](#cite_note-Greenberg-12)^ During the [Canaanite](/wiki/Canaanites "Canaanites") period (14th century BCE), Jerusalem was named as *Urusalim* on [ancient Egyptian](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") tablets, probably meaning "City of [Shalem](/wiki/Shalim "Shalim")" after a [Canaanite deity](/wiki/Canaanite_religion "Canaanite religion"). During the [Israelite](/wiki/Israelites "Israelites") period, significant construction activity in Jerusalem began in the 10th century BCE (Iron Age II), and by the 9th century BCE, the city had developed into the religious and administrative center of the [Kingdom of Judah](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah "Kingdom of Judah").^[\[10\]](#cite_note-13)^ In 1538, the [city walls were rebuilt](/wiki/Walls_of_Jerusalem "Walls of Jerusalem") for a last time around Jerusalem under [Suleiman the Magnificent](/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent "Suleiman the Magnificent") of the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"). Today those walls define the [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_of_Jerusalem "Old City of Jerusalem"), which since the 19th century has been divided into four quarters -- the [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_Quarter "Armenian Quarter"), [Christian](/wiki/Christian_Quarter "Christian Quarter"), [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem) "Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)"), and [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim_Quarter_(Jerusalem) "Muslim Quarter (Jerusalem)") quarters.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-14)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Teller-15)^ The Old City became a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1981, and is on the [List of World Heritage in Danger](/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_in_Danger "List of World Heritage in Danger").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-16)^ Since 1860, [Jerusalem has grown](/wiki/Expansion_of_Jerusalem_in_the_19th_century "Expansion of Jerusalem in the 19th century") far beyond the Old City's boundaries. In 2022, Jerusalem had a [population](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem "Demographic history of Jerusalem") of some 971,800 residents, of which almost 60% were Jews and almost 40% Palestinians.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-cbs.gov.il_2022-17)^^[\[note 4\]](#cite_note-19)^ In 2020, the population was 951,100, of which [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews") comprised 570,100 (59.9%), [Muslims](/wiki/Muslims "Muslims") 353,800 (37.2%), [Christians](/wiki/Christians "Christians") 16,300 (1.7%), and 10,800 unclassified (1.1%).^[\[16\]](#cite_note-PopRel-20)^{#cite_ref-PopRel_20-0}

According to the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Tanakh "Tanakh"), King [David](/wiki/David "David") [conquered the city](/wiki/Siege_of_Jebus "Siege of Jebus") from the [Jebusites](/wiki/Jebusite "Jebusite") and established it as the capital of the [United Kingdom of Israel](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy) "Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)"), and his son, King [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon "Solomon"), commissioned the building of the [First Temple](/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem "Temple in Jerusalem").^[\[note 5\]](#cite_note-bible-david-22)^ Modern scholars argue that Israelites branched out of the [Canaanite](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan") peoples and culture through the development of a distinct [monolatrous](/wiki/Monolatry "Monolatry")---and later [monotheistic](/wiki/Monotheism "Monotheism")---religion centered on [El](/wiki/El_(deity) "El (deity)")/[Yahweh](/wiki/Yahweh "Yahweh").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-Tubb98-23)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Smith02-24)^ These foundational events, straddling the dawn of the 1st millennium BCE, assumed central symbolic [importance](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Judaism "Jerusalem in Judaism") for the Jewish people.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-1000BCE-25)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-26)^ The sobriquet of holy city (Hebrew: עיר הקודש, romanized: *'Ir ha-Qodesh*) was probably attached to Jerusalem in [post-exilic](/wiki/Post-exilic "Post-exilic") times.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-27)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-29)^ The holiness of [Jerusalem in Christianity](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity "Jerusalem in Christianity"), conserved in the [Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Septuagint "Septuagint"),^[\[25\]](#cite_note-:5-30)^ which Christians adopted as the [Old Testament](/wiki/Old_Testament "Old Testament"),^[\[26\]](#cite_note-:6-31)^ was reinforced by the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") account of [Jesus's crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus") and [resurrection](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection of Jesus") there. Meanwhile, in [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam"), Jerusalem is the third-holiest city, after [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca") and [Medina](/wiki/Medina "Medina").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-3rd-32)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-33)^ The city was the first [standard direction](/wiki/Qibla "Qibla") for [Muslim prayers](/wiki/Salah "Salah"),^[\[29\]](#cite_note-:7-34)^ and [in Islamic tradition](/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam "Holiest sites in Islam"), [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad "Muhammad") made his [Night Journey](/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj "Isra and Mi'raj") there in 621, ascending to heaven where he spoke to [God](/wiki/God_in_Islam "God in Islam"), per the [Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-:9-35)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-36)^ As a result, despite having an area of only
0.9 km^2^ (3⁄8 sq mi),^[\[32\]](#cite_note-37)^ the Old City is home to many sites of seminal [religious importance](/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem "Religious significance of Jerusalem"), among them the [Temple Mount](/wiki/Temple_Mount "Temple Mount") with its [Western Wall](/wiki/Western_Wall "Western Wall"), [Dome of the Rock](/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock "Dome of the Rock") and [al-Aqsa Mosque](/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque "Al-Aqsa Mosque"), and the [Church of the Holy Sepulchre](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of the Holy Sepulchre").{#cite_ref-37}

At present, the [status of Jerusalem](/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem "Status of Jerusalem") remains one of the core issues in the [Israeli--Palestinian conflict](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict "Israeli–Palestinian conflict"). Under the 1947 [United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine](/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine "United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine"), Jerusalem was to be "established as a *[corpus separatum](/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem) "Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)")* under a special international regime" administered by the United Nations.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-38)^ During the [1948 Arab--Israeli War](/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War "1948 Arab–Israeli War"), [West Jerusalem](/wiki/West_Jerusalem "West Jerusalem") was among the areas [incorporated](/wiki/Battle_for_Jerusalem "Battle for Jerusalem") into Israel, while [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem"), including the Old City, was occupied and [annexed](/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank "Jordanian annexation of the West Bank") by [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan"). Israel occupied East Jerusalem from Jordan during the 1967 [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-Day_War "Six-Day War") and subsequently [annexed](/wiki/Israeli_annexation_of_East_Jerusalem "Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem") it into the city's municipality, together with additional surrounding territory.^[\[note 6\]](#cite_note-42)^ One of Israel's [Basic Laws](/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel "Basic Laws of Israel"), the 1980 [Jerusalem Law](/wiki/Jerusalem_Law "Jerusalem Law"), refers to Jerusalem as the country's undivided capital. All branches of the Israeli government are located in Jerusalem, including the [Knesset](/wiki/Knesset "Knesset") (Israel's parliament), the [residences of the prime minister](/wiki/Beit_Aghion "Beit Aghion") and [president](/wiki/Beit_HaNassi "Beit HaNassi"), and the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel "Supreme Court of Israel"). The [international community](/wiki/International_community "International community") rejects the annexation as illegal and regards East Jerusalem as [Palestinian territory occupied by Israel](/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_West_Bank "Israeli occupation of the West Bank").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-43)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-44)^^[\[39\]](#cite_note-45)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}  

Etymology and names {#Etymology_and_names}
------------------------------------------

Further information: [Names of Jerusalem](/wiki/Names_of_Jerusalem "Names of Jerusalem")  

### Etymology {#Etymology}

The name "Jerusalem" is variously etymologized to mean "foundation (Semitic *yry'* 'to found, to lay a cornerstone') of the pagan god [Shalem](/wiki/Shalim "Shalim")";^[\[41\]](#cite_note-47)^^[\[42\]](#cite_note-Binz-48)^ the god Shalem was thus the original [tutelary deity](/wiki/Tutelary_deity "Tutelary deity") of the Bronze Age city.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

Shalim or Shalem was the name of the god of dusk in the [Canaanite religion](/wiki/Canaanite_religion "Canaanite religion"), whose name is based on the same root [S-L-M](/wiki/S-L-M "S-L-M") from which the Hebrew word for "peace" is derived (*Shalom* in [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"), cognate with [Arabic](/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic "Modern Standard Arabic") *Salam* ).^[\[44\]](#cite_note-50)^^[\[45\]](#cite_note-51)^ The name thus offered itself to etymologizations such as "The City of Peace",^[\[42\]](#cite_note-Binz-48)^^[\[46\]](#cite_note-Hastings-52)^ "Abode of Peace",^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Bosworth-53)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-DeGarmo-54)^ "Dwelling of Peace" ("founded in safety"),^[\[49\]](#cite_note-55)^ or "Vision of Peace" in some Christian authors.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-Harrison-56)^{#cite_ref-Harrison_56-0}

The ending *-ayim* indicates the [dual](/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number) "Dual (grammatical number)"), thus leading to the suggestion that the name *Yerushalayim* refers to the fact that the city initially sat on two hills.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-57)^^[\[52\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}  

### Ancient Egyptian sources {#Ancient_Egyptian_sources}

The [Execration Texts](/wiki/Execration_Texts "Execration Texts") of the [Middle Kingdom of Egypt](/wiki/Middle_Kingdom_of_Egypt "Middle Kingdom of Egypt") (c. 19th century BCE), which refer to a city called *rwšꜣlmm* or *[ꜣwšꜣmm](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EA%9C%A3w%C5%A1%EA%9C%A3mm "wikt:ꜣwšꜣmm")* , variously transcribed as *Rušalimum* , or *Urušalimum* ,^[\[53\]](#cite_note-59)^^[\[54\]](#cite_note-60)^ may indicate Jerusalem.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-61)^^[\[56\]](#cite_note-62)^ Alternatively, the [Amarna letters](/wiki/Amarna_letters "Amarna letters") of [Abdi-Heba](/wiki/Abdi-Heba "Abdi-Heba") (1330s BCE), which reference an *Úrušalim* , may be the earliest mention of the city.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-vaughn-63)^^[\[58\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[59\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}  

### Hebrew Bible and Jewish sources {#Hebrew_Bible_and_Jewish_sources}

The form *Yerushalem* or *Yerushalayim* first appears in the Bible, in the [Book of Joshua](/wiki/Book_of_Joshua "Book of Joshua"). According to a [Midrash](/wiki/Midrash "Midrash"), the name is a combination of two names united by God, *Yireh* ("the abiding place", the name given by [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham") to the place where [he planned to sacrifice his son](/wiki/Binding_of_Isaac "Binding of Isaac")) and *[Shalem](/wiki/Salem_(Bible) "Salem (Bible)")* ("Place of Peace", the name given by high priest [Shem](/wiki/Shem "Shem")).^[\[60\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}  

### Oldest written mention of *Jerusalem* {#Oldest_written_mention_of_Jerusalem}

One of the earliest extra-biblical [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language") writing of the word *Jerusalem* is dated to the sixth or seventh century BCE^[\[61\]](#cite_note-67)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-68)^ and was discovered in [Khirbet Beit Lei](/wiki/Khirbet_Beit_Lei "Khirbet Beit Lei") near [Beit Guvrin](/wiki/Beit_Guvrin,_Israel "Beit Guvrin, Israel") in 1961. The inscription states: "I am Yahweh thy God, I will accept the cities of Judah and I will redeem Jerusalem",^[\[63\]](#cite_note-69)^^[\[64\]](#cite_note-70)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-71)^ or as other scholars suggest: "Yahweh is the God of the whole earth. The mountains of Judah belong to him, to the God of Jerusalem".^[\[66\]](#cite_note-Naveh2001-72)^^[\[67\]](#cite_note-73)^ An earlier example of the name appears in a papyrus from the 7th century BCE.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-74)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-Baruch-75)^{#cite_ref-Baruch_75-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg/220px-Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg)](/wiki/File:Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg) Close up of the [Khirbet Beit Lei inscription](/wiki/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_graffiti "Khirbet Beit Lei graffiti"), showing the earliest extra-biblical Hebrew writing of the word *Jerusalem*, dated to the seventh or sixth century BCE

In extra-biblical inscriptions, the earliest known example of the *-ayim* ending was discovered on a column about 3 km west of ancient Jerusalem, dated to the first century BCE.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-Baruch-75)^{#cite_ref-Baruch_75-1}  

### Jebus, Zion, City of David {#Jebus.2C_Zion.2C_City_of_David}

An ancient settlement of Jerusalem, founded as early as the Bronze Age on the hill above the [Gihon Spring](/wiki/Gihon_Spring "Gihon Spring"), was, according to the Bible, named [Jebus](/wiki/Jebusite "Jebusite").^[\[70\]](#cite_note-76)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-77)^^[\[72\]](#cite_note-Gagrinp113-78)^ Called the "Fortress of Zion" (*metsudat Zion* ), it was renamed as the "City of David",^[\[73\]](#cite_note-79)^ and was known by this name in antiquity.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-81)^ Another name, "[Zion](/wiki/Zion "Zion")", initially referred to a distinct part of the city, but later came to signify the city as a whole, and afterwards to represent the whole biblical [Land of Israel](/wiki/Land_of_Israel "Land of Israel").{#cite_ref-81}  

### Greek, Roman and Byzantine names {#Greek.2C_Roman_and_Byzantine_names}

In Greek and Latin, the city's name was transliterated *Hierosolyma/Hierosoluma* (Greek: Ἱεροσόλυμα; in Greek *hieròs* , *ἱερός* , means holy), and was the term used by [Matthew](/wiki/Matthew_the_Apostle "Matthew the Apostle") and [Mark](/wiki/Mark_the_Evangelist "Mark the Evangelist") in their [gospels](/wiki/Gospel "Gospel") instead of the Hebrew term.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-Hierosolyma-82)^{#cite_ref-Hierosolyma_82-0}

Up until the 2010s the consensus among [historians](/wiki/Historian "Historian") was that following [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great")'s conquest, Hierosoluma was set to be incorporated into the larger temple cities of the [Seleucid kingdom](/wiki/Seleucid_kingdom "Seleucid kingdom"), and to be [Hellenized](/wiki/Hellenized "Hellenized") as *Hierapolis.* ^[\[76\]](#cite_note-Hierosolyma-82)^ However, modern historians dispute this as a proper Ancient Greek translation for the [polis](/wiki/Polis "Polis") would be similar to *Hierolophos* .^[\[76\]](#cite_note-Hierosolyma-82)^{#cite_ref-Hierosolyma_82-2}

The city was renamed [Aelia Capitolina](/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina "Aelia Capitolina") for part of the [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") period of its history.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

### Salem {#Salem}

The [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_language "Aramaic language") [Apocryphon of Genesis](/wiki/Genesis_Apocryphon "Genesis Apocryphon") of the [Dead Sea Scrolls](/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls "Dead Sea Scrolls") (1QapGen 22:13) equates Jerusalem with the earlier "Salem" (שלם), said to be the kingdom of [Melchizedek](/wiki/Melchizedek "Melchizedek") in Genesis 14.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-83)^ Other early Hebrew sources,^[\[78\]](#cite_note-84)^ early Christian renderings of the verse^[\[79\]](#cite_note-85)^ and *[targumim](/wiki/Targumim "Targumim")* ,^[\[80\]](#cite_note-86)^ however, put Salem in Northern Israel near [Shechem](/wiki/Shechem "Shechem") (Sichem), now [Nablus](/wiki/Nablus "Nablus"), a city of some importance in early sacred Hebrew writing.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-87)^ Possibly the redactor of the Apocryphon of Genesis wanted to dissociate Melchizedek from the area of Shechem, which at the time was in possession of the [Samaritans](/wiki/Samaritans "Samaritans").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-88)^ However that may be, later Rabbinic sources also equate Salem with Jerusalem, mainly to link Melchizedek to later Temple traditions.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-89)^{#cite_ref-89}  

### Arabic names {#Arabic_names}

"Al-Quds" redirects here. For other uses, see [Al-Quds (disambiguation)](/wiki/Al-Quds_(disambiguation) "Al-Quds (disambiguation)").

Originally titled Bayt al-Maqdis, today, Jerusalem is most commonly known in [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") as القُدس, transliterated as *al-Quds* and meaning "the holy" or "the holy sanctuary",^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Bosworth-53)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-DeGarmo-54)^ cognate with [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): הקדש, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Hebrew "Romanization of Hebrew"): *ha-qodesh*. The name is possibly a shortened form of مدينة القُدس *Madīnat al-Quds* "city of the holy sanctuary" after the Hebrew nickname with the same meaning, *Ir ha-Qodesh* (עיר הקדש). The ق (Q) is pronounced either with a [voiceless uvular plosive](/wiki/Voiceless_uvular_plosive "Voiceless uvular plosive") (/q/), as in [Classical Arabic](/wiki/Classical_Arabic "Classical Arabic"), or with a [glottal stop](/wiki/Glottal_stop "Glottal stop") (ʔ) as in [Levantine Arabic](/wiki/Levantine_Arabic "Levantine Arabic").^[\[6\]](#cite_note-Elihay2011-7)^ Official Israeli government policy mandates that أُورُشَلِيمَ, transliterated as *Ūrušalīm* , which is the name frequently used in Christian translations of the Bible into Arabic,^[\[84\]](#cite_note-90)^^[\[85\]](#cite_note-91)^ be used as the Arabic language name for the city in conjunction with القُدس, giving أُورُشَلِيمَ-القُدس, Ūrušalīm-al-Quds.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-92)^ Palestinian Arab families who hail from this city are often called "*Qudsi* " (قُدسي) or "*Maqdasi* " (مقدسي), while Palestinian Muslim Jerusalemites may use these terms as a [demonym](/wiki/Demonym "Demonym").^[\[87\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of Jerusalem](/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem "History of Jerusalem")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Jerusalem](/wiki/Timeline_of_Jerusalem "Timeline of Jerusalem").  
See also: [Historical maps of Jerusalem](/wiki/Cartography_of_Jerusalem "Cartography of Jerusalem")

Jerusalem is one of the world's oldest cities, with a history spanning over 5,000 years. Its origins trace back to around 3000 BCE, with the first settlement near the [Gihon Spring](/wiki/Gihon_Spring "Gihon Spring"). The city is first mentioned in Egyptian [Execration texts](/wiki/Execration_texts "Execration texts") around 2000 BCE as "Rusalimum." By the 17th century BCE, Jerusalem had developed into a fortified city under [Canaanite](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan") rule, with massive walls protecting its water system. During the [Late Bronze Age](/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age "Late Bronze Age"), Jerusalem became a vassal of [Ancient Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt"), as documented in the [Amarna letters](/wiki/Amarna_letters "Amarna letters").

The city's importance grew during the *Israelite period* , which began around 1000 BCE when [King David](/wiki/King_David "King David") captured Jerusalem and made it the capital of the [United Kingdom of Israel](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Israel "United Kingdom of Israel"). David's son, [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon "Solomon"), built the [First Temple](/wiki/First_Temple "First Temple"), establishing the city as a major religious center. Following the kingdom's split, Jerusalem became the capital of the [Kingdom of Judah](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah "Kingdom of Judah") until it was captured by the [Neo-Babylonian Empire](/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire "Neo-Babylonian Empire") in 586 BCE. The [Babylonians](/wiki/Babylonians "Babylonians") destroyed the First Temple, leading to the [Babylonian exile](/wiki/Babylonian_exile "Babylonian exile") of the Jewish population. After the Persian conquest of Babylon in 539 BCE, [Cyrus the Great](/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great "Cyrus the Great") allowed the Jews to return and rebuild the city and its temple, marking the start of the *Second Temple period* . Jerusalem fell under [Hellenistic](/wiki/Hellenistic "Hellenistic") rule after the conquests of [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great") in 332 BCE, leading to increasing cultural and political influence from [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"). The [Hasmonean](/wiki/Hasmonean "Hasmonean") revolt in 164 BCE briefly restored Jewish autonomy, with Jerusalem as the capital of an independent state.

In 63 BCE, Jerusalem was conquered by [Pompey](/wiki/Pompey "Pompey") and became part of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"). The city remained under Roman control until the [Jewish-Roman Wars](/wiki/Jewish-Roman_Wars "Jewish-Roman Wars"), which culminated in the destruction of the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second Temple") in 70 CE. The city was renamed *Aelia Capitolina* and rebuilt as a Roman colony after the [Bar Kokhba revolt](/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt "Bar Kokhba revolt") (132--136 CE), with Jews banned from entering the city. Jerusalem gained significance during the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") as a center of [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), particularly after [Constantine the Great](/wiki/Constantine_the_Great "Constantine the Great") endorsed the construction of the [Church of the Holy Sepulchre](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of the Holy Sepulchre"). In 638 CE, Jerusalem was conquered by the [Rashidun Caliphate](/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate "Rashidun Caliphate"), and under early [Islamic](/wiki/Islamic "Islamic") rule, the [Dome of the Rock](/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock "Dome of the Rock") and [Al-Aqsa Mosque](/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque "Al-Aqsa Mosque") were built, solidifying its religious importance in Islam.

During the [Crusades](/wiki/Crusades "Crusades"), Jerusalem changed hands multiple times, being captured by the Crusaders in 1099 and recaptured by [Saladin](/wiki/Saladin "Saladin") in 1187. It remained under [Islamic](/wiki/Islamic "Islamic") control through the [Ayyubid](/wiki/Ayyubid "Ayyubid") and [Mamluk](/wiki/Mamluk "Mamluk") periods, until it became part of the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in 1517. In the modern period, Jerusalem was divided between Israel and Jordan after the [1948 Arab--Israeli War](/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War "1948 Arab–Israeli War"). Israel captured [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem") during the [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-Day_War "Six-Day War") in 1967, uniting the city under Israeli control. The [status of Jerusalem](/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem "Status of Jerusalem") remains a highly contentious issue, with both Israelis and Palestinians claiming it as their capital. Historiographically, the city's history is often interpreted through the lens of competing national narratives. [Israeli](/wiki/Israelis "Israelis") scholars emphasize the ancient Jewish connection to the city, while [Palestinian](/wiki/Palestinian "Palestinian") narratives highlight the city's broader historical and multicultural significance. Both perspectives influence contemporary discussions of Jerusalem's status and future.  

Political status {#Political_status}
------------------------------------

Main article: [Positions on Jerusalem](/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem "Positions on Jerusalem")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Stamp_of_Israel_-_Festivals_5729_-_15.jpg/145px-Stamp_of_Israel_-_Festivals_5729_-_15.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stamp_of_Israel_-_Festivals_5729_-_15.jpg) An Israeli stamp from 1968, quoting   
[Psalm 122](/wiki/Psalm_122 "Psalm 122"):6;   
*Pray for the peace of Jerusalem!...*

From 1923 until 1948, Jerusalem served as the administrative capital of [Mandatory Palestine](/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine "Mandatory Palestine").^[\[88\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

From 1949 until 1967, West Jerusalem served as Israel's capital, but was not recognized as such internationally because [UN General Assembly Resolution 194](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_194 "United Nations General Assembly Resolution 194") envisaged Jerusalem as an [international city](/wiki/International_city "International city"). As a result of the Six-Day War in 1967, the whole of Jerusalem [came under Israeli control](/wiki/Reunification_of_Jerusalem "Reunification of Jerusalem"). On 27 June 1967, the government of [Levi Eshkol](/wiki/Levi_Eshkol "Levi Eshkol") extended Israeli law and jurisdiction to East Jerusalem, but agreed that administration of the Temple Mount compound would be maintained by the [Jordanian waqf](/wiki/Jerusalem_Islamic_Waqf "Jerusalem Islamic Waqf"), under the Jordanian Ministry of Religious Endowments.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}

In 1988, Israel ordered the closure of [Orient House](/wiki/Orient_House "Orient House"), home of the Arab Studies Society, but also the headquarters of the [Palestine Liberation Organization](/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization "Palestine Liberation Organization"), for security reasons. The building reopened in 1992 as a Palestinian guesthouse.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-96)^^[\[91\]](#cite_note-97)^ The [Oslo Accords](/wiki/Oslo_Accords "Oslo Accords") stated that the final status of Jerusalem would be determined by negotiations with the [Palestinian Authority](/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority "Palestinian National Authority"). The accords banned any official Palestinian presence in the city until a final peace agreement, but provided for the opening of a Palestinian trade office in East Jerusalem. The Palestinian Authority regards East Jerusalem as the capital of a future Palestinian state.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-umd-98)^^[\[93\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}

President [Mahmoud Abbas](/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas "Mahmoud Abbas") has said that any agreement that did not include East Jerusalem as the capital of Palestine would be unacceptable.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-100)^ Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has similarly stated that Jerusalem would remain the undivided capital of Israel. Due to its proximity to the city, especially the Temple Mount, [Abu Dis](/wiki/Abu_Dis "Abu Dis"), a Palestinian suburb of Jerusalem, has been proposed as the future capital of a Palestinian state by Israel. Israel has not incorporated Abu Dis within its security wall around Jerusalem. The Palestinian Authority has built a possible future parliament building for the [Palestinian Legislative Council](/wiki/Palestinian_Legislative_Council "Palestinian Legislative Council") in the town, and its Jerusalem Affairs Offices are all located in Abu Dis.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### International status {#International_status}

While the international community regards East Jerusalem, including the entire Old City, as part of the [occupied Palestinian territories](/wiki/Occupied_Palestinian_territories "Occupied Palestinian territories"), neither part, West or East Jerusalem, is recognized as part of the territory of Israel or the [State of Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine").^[\[96\]](#cite_note-102)^^[\[97\]](#cite_note-103)^^[\[98\]](#cite_note-104)^^[\[99\]](#cite_note-105)^ Under the [United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine](/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine "United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine") adopted by the [General Assembly of the United Nations](/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_United_Nations "General Assembly of the United Nations") in 1947, Jerusalem was envisaged to become a [corpus separatum](/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem) "Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)") administered by the United Nations. In the war of 1948, the western part of the city was occupied by forces of the nascent state of Israel, while the eastern part was occupied by Jordan. The international community largely considers the legal status of Jerusalem to derive from the partition plan, and correspondingly refuses to recognize Israeli sovereignty over the city.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}  

### Status under Israeli rule {#Status_under_Israeli_rule}

Following the 1967 Six-Day War, Israel extended its jurisdiction and administration over East Jerusalem, establishing new municipal borders.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/KnessetBuildingNov152022.jpg/220px-KnessetBuildingNov152022.jpg)](/wiki/File:KnessetBuildingNov152022.jpg) The [Knesset](/wiki/Knesset "Knesset") houses the [legislature](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature") of Israel

In 2010, Israel approved legislation giving Jerusalem the highest national priority status in Israel. The law prioritized construction throughout the city, and offered grants and tax benefits to residents to make housing, infrastructure, education, employment, business, tourism, and cultural events more affordable. Communications Minister [Moshe Kahlon](/wiki/Moshe_Kahlon "Moshe Kahlon") said that the bill sent "a clear, unequivocal political message that Jerusalem will not be divided", and that "all those within the Palestinian and international community who expect the current Israeli government to accept any demands regarding Israel's sovereignty over its capital are mistaken and misleading".^[\[101\]](#cite_note-107)^{#cite_ref-107}

The status of the city, and especially its holy places, remains a core issue in the Israeli--Palestinian conflict. The Israeli government has approved building plans in the Muslim Quarter of the Old City^[\[102\]](#cite_note-108)^ in order to expand the Jewish presence in East Jerusalem, while some Islamic leaders have made claims that Jews have no historical connection to Jerusalem, alleging that the 2,500-year-old Western Wall was constructed as part of a mosque.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[104\]](#cite_note-110)^ Palestinians regard Jerusalem as the capital of the [State of Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine"),^[\[105\]](#cite_note-PalestinianPosition-111)^ and the city's borders have been the subject of bilateral talks. A team of experts assembled by the then Israeli Prime Minister [Ehud Barak](/wiki/Ehud_Barak "Ehud Barak") in 2000 concluded that the city must be divided, since Israel had failed to achieve any of its national aims there.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-Amirav01a-112)^{#cite_ref-Amirav01a_112-0}

However, Israeli Prime Minister [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu") said in 2014 that "Jerusalem will never be divided".^[\[107\]](#cite_note-113)^ A poll conducted in June 2013 found that 74% of Israeli Jews reject the idea of a Palestinian capital in any portion of Jerusalem, though 72% of the public regarded it as a divided city.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-114)^ A poll conducted by Palestinian Centre for Public Opinion and American Pechter Middle East Polls for the Council on Foreign Relations, among East Jerusalem Arab residents in 2011 revealed that 39% of East Jerusalem Arab residents would prefer Israeli citizenship contrary to 31% who opted for Palestinian citizenship. According to the poll, 40% of Palestinian residents would prefer to leave their neighbourhoods if they would be placed under Palestinian rule.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg)](/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg) The [Supreme Court of Israel](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel "Supreme Court of Israel")  

### Jerusalem as capital of Israel {#Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Israel}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Hutz.JPG/220px-Hutz.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hutz.JPG) The [Israeli Foreign Ministry](/wiki/Foreign_Ministry_of_Israel "Foreign Ministry of Israel") building

On 5 December 1949, Israel's first Prime Minister, [David Ben-Gurion](/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion "David Ben-Gurion"), proclaimed Jerusalem as Israel's "eternal" and "sacred" capital, and eight days later specified that only the war had "compelled" the Israeli leadership "to establish the seat of Government in Tel Aviv", while "for the State of Israel there has always been and always will be one capital only -- Jerusalem the Eternal", and that after the war, efforts had been ongoing for creating the conditions for "the Knesset... returning to Jerusalem."^[\[110\]](#cite_note-BGurion-116)^ This indeed took place, and since the beginning of 1950 all branches of the [Israeli government](/wiki/Politics_of_Israel "Politics of Israel")---[legislative](/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Legislative_branch "Politics of Israel"), [judicial](/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Judicial_system "Politics of Israel"), and [executive](/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Prime_Ministers_and_governments_in_the_last_ten_years "Politics of Israel")---have resided there, except for the [Ministry of Defense](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Israel) "Ministry of Defense (Israel)"), which is located at [HaKirya](/wiki/HaKirya "HaKirya") in [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-117)^^[\[112\]](#cite_note-JTA-118)^ At the time of Ben Gurion's proclamations and the ensuing Knesset vote of 24 January 1950,^[\[112\]](#cite_note-JTA-118)^ Jerusalem was divided between Israel and Jordan, and thus the proclamation only applied to West Jerusalem.{#cite_ref-JTA_118-1}

In July 1980, Israel passed the [Jerusalem Law](/wiki/Jerusalem_Law "Jerusalem Law") as [Basic Law](/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel "Basic Laws of Israel"). The law declared Jerusalem the "complete and united" capital of Israel.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-basiclaw-119)^ The Jerusalem Law was condemned by the international community, which did not recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. The United Nations Security Council passed [Resolution 478](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 478") on 20 August 1980, which declared that the Jerusalem Law is *"a violation of international law"* , is *"null and void and must be rescinded forthwith"* . Member states were called upon to withdraw their diplomatic representation from Jerusalem.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-120)^{#cite_ref-120}

Following the resolution, 22 of the 24 countries that previously had their embassy in (West) Jerusalem relocated them in Tel Aviv, where many embassies already resided prior to Resolution 478. [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica") and [El Salvador](/wiki/El_Salvador "El Salvador") followed in 2006.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-121)^ There are five embassies---United States, Guatemala, Honduras, Papua-New Guinea and Kosovo ---and two consulates located within the city limits of Jerusalem, and two [Latin American](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") states maintain embassies in the [Jerusalem District](/wiki/Jerusalem_District "Jerusalem District") [town](/wiki/Local_council_(Israel) "Local council (Israel)") of [Mevaseret Zion](/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion "Mevaseret Zion") ([Bolivia](/wiki/Bolivia "Bolivia") and [Paraguay](/wiki/Paraguay "Paraguay")).^[\[116\]](#cite_note-embassies-122)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-123)^^[\[118\]](#cite_note-124)^^[\[119\]](#cite_note-125)^ There are [a number of consulates-general](/wiki/List_of_Consulates-General_in_Jerusalem "List of Consulates-General in Jerusalem") located in Jerusalem, which work primarily either with Israel, or the Palestinian authorities.{#cite_ref-125}

In 1995, the United States Congress passed the [Jerusalem Embassy Act](/wiki/Jerusalem_Embassy_Act "Jerusalem Embassy Act"), which required, subject to conditions, that its embassy be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-126)^ On 6 December 2017 [U.S. President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") officially [recognized Jerusalem](/wiki/United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Israel "United States recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel") as Israel's capital and announced his intention to move the [American embassy](/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Tel_Aviv "Embassy of the United States, Tel Aviv") to Jerusalem, reversing decades of United States policy on the issue.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-127)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-128)^ The move was criticized by many nations.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-129)^ A resolution condemning the US decision was supported by all the 14 other members of the UN Security Council, but was vetoed by the US on 18 December 2017.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-130)^ A subsequent resolution condemning the US decision was passed in the [United Nations General Assembly](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly "United Nations General Assembly").^[\[125\]](#cite_note-131)^^[\[126\]](#cite_note-132)^^[\[127\]](#cite_note-133)^^[\[128\]](#cite_note-134)^ On 14 May 2018, the United States officially opened its [embassy in Jerusalem](/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Jerusalem "Embassy of the United States, Jerusalem"), transforming its Tel Aviv location into a consulate. Due to the general lack of international recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital, some non-Israeli media outlets use Tel Aviv as a [metonym](/wiki/Metonym "Metonym") for Israel.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-135)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-136)^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-137)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-138)^{#cite_ref-138}

In April 2017, the Russian Foreign Ministry announced it viewed Western Jerusalem as Israel's capital in the context of UN-approved principles which include the status of East Jerusalem as the capital of the future Palestinian state.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-139)^^[\[134\]](#cite_note-140)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-141)^ On 15 December 2018, [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") officially recognized West Jerusalem as Israel's capital, but said their embassy in Tel Aviv would stay until a two-state resolution was settled.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-142)^ The decision was reversed in October 2022.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-aureverse-143)^{#cite_ref-aureverse_143-0}  

#### Government precinct and national institutions {#Government_precinct_and_national_institutions}

The [Kiryat HaLeom](/wiki/Kiryat_HaLeom "Kiryat HaLeom") (national precinct) project is intended to house most government agencies and national cultural institutions. They are located in the [Kiryat HaMemshala](/wiki/Kiryat_HaMemshala "Kiryat HaMemshala") (government complex) in the [Givat Ram](/wiki/Givat_Ram "Givat Ram") neighbourhood. Some government buildings are located in [Kiryat Menachem Begin](/wiki/Kiryat_Menachem_Begin "Kiryat Menachem Begin"). The city is home to the Knesset,^[\[138\]](#cite_note-144)^ the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel "Supreme Court of Israel"),^[\[139\]](#cite_note-145)^ the [Bank of Israel](/wiki/Bank_of_Israel "Bank of Israel"), the [National Headquarters of the Israel Police](/wiki/National_Headquarters_of_the_Israel_Police "National Headquarters of the Israel Police"), the official residences of the [President](/wiki/President_of_Israel "President of Israel") and [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel "Prime Minister of Israel"), the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel "Cabinet of Israel"), and all ministries except for the [Ministry of Defense](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Israel) "Ministry of Defense (Israel)") (which is located in central Tel Aviv's [HaKirya](/wiki/HaKirya "HaKirya") district) and the [Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development_(Israel) "Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (Israel)") (which is located in [Rishon LeZion](/wiki/Rishon_LeZion "Rishon LeZion"), in the wider Tel Aviv [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area"), near [Beit Dagan](/wiki/Beit_Dagan "Beit Dagan")).{#cite_ref-145}

Since its capture in 1967, the Israeli government has built 12 [Israeli settlements](/wiki/Israeli_settlements "Israeli settlements") in [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem"), with a population amounting to 220,000 Israeli Jewish settlers as of 2019.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-146)^ The international community consider Israeli settlements to be illegal under [international law](/wiki/International_law "International law").^[\[141\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}  

### Jerusalem as capital of Palestine {#Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Palestine}

See also: [East Jerusalem § Jerusalem as capital](/wiki/East_Jerusalem#Jerusalem_as_capital "East Jerusalem")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Orient_House.jpg/220px-Orient_House.jpg)](/wiki/File:Orient_House.jpg) The Orient House, Jerusalem the former headquarters of the PLO [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/French_Consulate_in_Jerusalem_at_night_2008.jpg/220px-French_Consulate_in_Jerusalem_at_night_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:French_Consulate_in_Jerusalem_at_night_2008.jpg) The [Consulate General of France, Jerusalem](/wiki/Consulate_General_of_France,_Jerusalem "Consulate General of France, Jerusalem")

The [Palestinian National Authority](/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority "Palestinian National Authority") views East Jerusalem as [occupied territory](/wiki/Occupied_territory "Occupied territory") according to [United Nations Security Council Resolution 242](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_242 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 242"). The Palestinian Authority claims Jerusalem, including the [Haram al-Sharif](/wiki/Haram_al-Sharif "Haram al-Sharif"), as the capital of the State of Palestine,^[\[105\]](#cite_note-PalestinianPosition-111)^ The PLO claims that West Jerusalem is also subject to permanent status negotiations. However, it has stated that it would be willing to consider alternative solutions, such as making Jerusalem an [open city](/wiki/Open_city "Open city").^[\[142\]](#cite_note-PLO-NAD-148)^{#cite_ref-PLO-NAD_148-0}

The PLO's position is that East Jerusalem, as defined by the [pre-1967 municipal boundaries](/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel) "Green Line (Israel)"), shall be the capital of Palestine and [West Jerusalem](/wiki/West_Jerusalem "West Jerusalem") the capital of Israel, with each state enjoying full sovereignty over its respective part of the city and with its own municipality. A joint *development council* would be responsible for coordinated development.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-149)^ [Orient House](/wiki/Orient_House "Orient House") in East Jerusalem served as the headquarters of the [PLO](/wiki/PLO "PLO") in the 1980s and 1990s. It was closed by Israel in 2001, two days after the [Sbarro restaurant suicide bombing](/wiki/Sbarro_restaurant_suicide_bombing "Sbarro restaurant suicide bombing").{#cite_ref-149}

Some states, such as [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")^[\[144\]](#cite_note-150)^ and [China](/wiki/China "China"),^[\[145\]](#cite_note-151)^ recognize the Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital. [United Nations General Assembly Resolution 58/292](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_58/292 "United Nations General Assembly Resolution 58/292") affirmed that the Palestinian people have the right to sovereignty over East Jerusalem.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}  

#### Palestinian offices and institutions {#Palestinian_offices_and_institutions}

See also: [List of diplomatic missions in Palestine § Consulates](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Palestine#Consulates "List of diplomatic missions in Palestine")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/89480_jerusalem_villa_constantine_salama_PikiWiki_Israel.jpg/220px-89480_jerusalem_villa_constantine_salama_PikiWiki_Israel.jpg)](/wiki/File:89480_jerusalem_villa_constantine_salama_PikiWiki_Israel.jpg) [Villa Salameh](/wiki/Villa_Salameh "Villa Salameh") --- the home of the Belgian Consulate to Palestine

Government offices are located outside the Israeli municipal limits include the [Palestinian Security Services](/wiki/Palestinian_Security_Services "Palestinian Security Services"), [Force 17](/wiki/Force_17 "Force 17"), the [Preventative Security Service](/wiki/Preventative_Security_Service "Preventative Security Service") and the [Ministry of Interior](/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(State_of_Palestine) "Ministry of Interior (State of Palestine)").^[\[147\]](#cite_note-153)^^[\[148\]](#cite_note-154)^^[\[149\]](#cite_note-155)^ There is a Palestinian Authority regional office and an electoral office located in the [Dahiyat al Barid](/wiki/Al-Ram "Al-Ram") neighborhood.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}  

Municipal administration {#Municipal_administration}
----------------------------------------------------

Main article: [Municipality of Jerusalem](/wiki/Municipality_of_Jerusalem "Municipality of Jerusalem")

The Jerusalem [City Council](/wiki/City_council "City council") is a body of 31 elected members headed by the mayor, who serves a five-year term and appoints eight deputies. The former mayor of Jerusalem, [Uri Lupolianski](/wiki/Uri_Lupolianski "Uri Lupolianski"), was elected in 2003.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-corridors-157)^ In the November 2008 city elections, [Nir Barkat](/wiki/Nir_Barkat "Nir Barkat") was elected. In November 2018, [Moshe Lion](/wiki/Moshe_Lion "Moshe Lion") was elected mayor.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

Apart from the mayor and his deputies, City Council members receive no salaries and work on a voluntary basis. The longest-serving Jerusalem mayor was [Teddy Kollek](/wiki/Teddy_Kollek "Teddy Kollek"), who spent 28 years---six consecutive terms---in office. Most of the meetings of the Jerusalem City Council are private, but each month, it holds a session that is open to the public.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-corridors-157)^ Within the city council, religious political parties form an especially powerful faction, accounting for the majority of its seats.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

The headquarters of the Jerusalem Municipality and the mayor's office are at [Safra Square](/wiki/Safra_Square "Safra Square") (*Kikar Safra* ) on [Jaffa Road](/wiki/Jaffa_Road "Jaffa Road"). The municipal complex, comprising two modern buildings and ten renovated historic buildings surrounding a large plaza, opened in 1993 when it moved from the [old town hall](/wiki/Jerusalem_Old_Town_Hall "Jerusalem Old Town Hall") building built by the [Mandate authorities](/wiki/Mandate_Palestine "Mandate Palestine").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-160)^ The city falls under the [Jerusalem District](/wiki/Jerusalem_District "Jerusalem District"), with Jerusalem as the district's capital. 37% of the population is Palestinian, but in 2014 not more than 10% of tax revenues were allocated for them. In East Jerusalem, 52% of the land was excluded from development, 35% designated for Jewish settlements, and 13% for Palestinian use, almost all of which was already built upon.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-Thrall-161)^{#cite_ref-Thrall_161-0}

In [Oslo I Accord](/wiki/Oslo_I_Accord "Oslo I Accord"), certain parts of few neighborhoods were allotted to the [Palestinian Authority](/wiki/Palestinian_Authority "Palestinian Authority"). Parts of [Sur Baher](/wiki/Sur_Baher "Sur Baher"), Wadi al-Hummus, [Umm Leisun](/wiki/Umm_Leisun_inscription "Umm Leisun inscription") and [Umm Tuba](/wiki/Umm_Tuba "Umm Tuba"), altogether came under [Area A](/wiki/Area_A "Area A"), which is completely controlled by the Palestinian Authority.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-162)^ [Al-Ram](/wiki/Al-Ram "Al-Ram") and [Dahiyat al-Barid](/wiki/Al-Ram "Al-Ram") are mostly in [Area B](/wiki/Area_B "Area B"), where both Palestine and Israel has control.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-163)^ Other parts of [Beit Hanina](/wiki/Beit_Hanina "Beit Hanina"), [Kafr Aqab](/wiki/Kafr_Aqab "Kafr Aqab") and [Arab al-Jahalin](/wiki/%27Arab_al-Jahalin "'Arab al-Jahalin") also falls under Area B.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-164)^^[\[159\]](#cite_note-ARIJ-165)^^[\[160\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg/1000px-Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg "A panorama of the Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound), including Al-Aqsa Mosque, and Dome of the Rock, from the Mount of Olives")  
[](/wiki/File:Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg "File:Panorámica de Jerusalén desde el Monte de los Olivos.jpg")
A panorama of the [Temple Mount](/wiki/Temple_Mount "Temple Mount") (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound), including [Al-Aqsa Mosque](/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque "Al-Aqsa Mosque"), and [Dome of the Rock](/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock "Dome of the Rock"), from the [Mount of Olives](/wiki/Mount_of_Olives "Mount of Olives")

Jerusalem is situated on the southern spur of a [plateau](/wiki/Plateau "Plateau") in the [Judaean Mountains](/wiki/Judaean_Mountains "Judaean Mountains"), which include the [Mount of Olives](/wiki/Mount_of_Olives "Mount of Olives") (East) and [Mount Scopus](/wiki/Mount_Scopus "Mount Scopus") (North East). The elevation of the Old City is approximately 760 m (2,490 ft).^[\[161\]](#cite_note-167)^ The whole of Jerusalem is surrounded by valleys and dry [riverbeds](/wiki/Wadi "Wadi") (*[wadis](/wiki/Wadi "Wadi")* ). The [Kidron](/wiki/Kidron_Valley "Kidron Valley"), [Hinnom](/wiki/Gehenna "Gehenna"), and [Tyropoeon](/wiki/Tyropoeon_Valley "Tyropoeon Valley") Valleys intersect in an area just south of the Old City of Jerusalem.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-bergsohn-168)^ The [Kidron Valley](/wiki/Kidron_Valley "Kidron Valley") runs to the east of the Old City and separates the [Mount of Olives](/wiki/Mount_of_Olives "Mount of Olives") from the city proper. Along the southern side of old Jerusalem is the [Valley of Hinnom](/wiki/Gehenna "Gehenna"), a steep ravine associated in biblical [eschatology](/wiki/Eschatology "Eschatology") with the concept of [Gehenna](/wiki/Gehenna "Gehenna") or [Hell](/wiki/Hell "Hell").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-169)^{#cite_ref-169}

The [Tyropoeon Valley](/wiki/Tyropoeon_Valley "Tyropoeon Valley") commenced in the northwest near the [Damascus Gate](/wiki/Damascus_Gate "Damascus Gate"), ran south-southeasterly through the centre of the Old City down to the [Pool of Siloam](/wiki/Pool_of_Siloam "Pool of Siloam"), and divided the lower part into two hills, the Temple Mount to the east, and the rest of the city to the west, the lower and the upper cities described by [Josephus](/wiki/Josephus "Josephus"). Today, this valley is hidden by debris that has accumulated over the centuries.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-bergsohn-168)^ In biblical times, Jerusalem was surrounded by forests of almond, olive and pine trees. Over centuries of warfare and neglect, these forests were destroyed. Farmers in the Jerusalem region built stone terraces along the slopes to hold back the soil, a feature still very much in evidence in the Jerusalem landscape.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-bergsohn_168-1}

Water supply has always been a major problem in Jerusalem, as attested to by the intricate network of ancient [aqueducts](/wiki/Aqueduct_(watercourse) "Aqueduct (watercourse)"), tunnels, pools and cisterns found in the city.^[\[164\]](#cite_note-170)^{#cite_ref-170}

Jerusalem is 60 km (37 mi)^[\[165\]](#cite_note-171)^ east of [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv") and the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea"). On the opposite side of the city, approximately 35 km (22 mi)^[\[166\]](#cite_note-172)^ away, is the [Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea"), the [lowest body of water](/wiki/Extremes_on_Earth "Extremes on Earth") on Earth. Neighbouring cities and towns include [Bethlehem](/wiki/Bethlehem "Bethlehem") and [Beit Jala](/wiki/Beit_Jala "Beit Jala") to the south, [Abu Dis](/wiki/Abu_Dis "Abu Dis") and [Ma'ale Adumim](/wiki/Ma%27ale_Adumim "Ma'ale Adumim") to the east, [Mevaseret Zion](/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion "Mevaseret Zion") to the west, and Ramallah and [Giv'at Ze'ev](/wiki/Giv%27at_Ze%27ev "Giv'at Ze'ev") to the north.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-173)^^[\[168\]](#cite_note-map-174)^^[\[169\]](#cite_note-175)^{#cite_ref-175}

[Mount Herzl](/wiki/Mount_Herzl "Mount Herzl"), at the western side of the city near the [Jerusalem Forest](/wiki/Jerusalem_Forest "Jerusalem Forest"), serves as the national cemetery of Israel.

### Climate {#Climate}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg/220px-%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg) Snow visible on roofs in the Old City of Jerusalem

The city is characterized by a [hot-summer Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Hot-summer_Mediterranean_climate "Hot-summer Mediterranean climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Csa* ), with hot, dry summers, and mild, wet winters. Snow flurries usually occur once or twice a winter, although the city experiences heavy [snowfall](/wiki/Snowfall "Snowfall") every three to four years, on average, with short-lived accumulation.

January is the coldest month of the year, with an average temperature of 9.1 °C (48.4 °F); July and August are the hottest months, with an average temperature of 24.2 °C (75.6 °F), and the summer months are usually rainless. The average annual precipitation is around 537 mm (21 in), with rain occurring almost entirely between October and May.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-weather-176)^ Snowfall is rare, and large snowfalls are even more rare.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-snow2013-1-177)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-snow2013-2-178)^ Jerusalem received over 30 cm (12 in) of snow on 13 December 2013, which nearly paralyzed the city.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-snow2013-1-177)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-snow2013-2-178)^ A day in Jerusalem has on average, 9.3 sunshine hours. With summers averaging similar temperatures as the coastline, the maritime influence from the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") is strong, in particular given that Jerusalem is located on a similar latitude as scorching hot deserts not far to its east.{#cite_ref-snow2013-2_178-1}

The highest recorded temperature in Jerusalem was 44.4 °C (111.9 °F) on 28 and 30 August 1881, and the lowest temperature recorded was −6.7 °C (19.9 °F) on 25 January 1907.

Most of the air pollution in Jerusalem comes from vehicular traffic.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-friction-179)^ Many main streets in Jerusalem were not built to accommodate such a large volume of traffic, leading to traffic congestion and more [carbon monoxide](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide "Carbon monoxide") released into the air. Industrial pollution inside the city is sparse, but emissions from factories on the [Israeli Mediterranean coast](/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain "Israeli coastal plain") can travel eastward and settle over the city.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-friction-179)^^[\[174\]](#cite_note-180)^{#cite_ref-180}

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

### Demographic history {#Demographic_history}

Main article: [Demographic history of Jerusalem](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem "Demographic history of Jerusalem")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png/361px-Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png)](/wiki/File:Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png) Demographic history of Jerusalem by religion based on available data

Jerusalem's population size and composition has shifted many times over its 5,000-year history. Since the 19th century, the [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem) "Old City (Jerusalem)") of Jerusalem has been divided into [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem) "Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)"), [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim_Quarter_(Jerusalem) "Muslim Quarter (Jerusalem)"), [Christian](/wiki/Christian_Quarter "Christian Quarter"), and [Armenian quarters](/wiki/Armenian_Quarter "Armenian Quarter"). Matthew Teller writes that this convention may have originated in the [1841 British Royal Engineers map of Jerusalem](/wiki/1840%E2%80%9341_Royal_Engineers_maps_of_Palestine,_Lebanon_and_Syria "1840–41 Royal Engineers maps of Palestine, Lebanon and Syria"),^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Teller-15)^ or at least Reverend [George Williams](/wiki/George_Williams_(priest) "George Williams (priest)")' subsequent labelling of it.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-Teller2-185)^{#cite_ref-Teller2_185-0}

Most population data before 1905 is based on estimates, often from foreign travellers or organisations, since previous census data usually covered wider areas such as the [Jerusalem District](/wiki/Jerusalem_District "Jerusalem District").^[\[180\]](#cite_note-186)^ These estimates suggest that since the end of the [Crusades](/wiki/Crusades "Crusades"), Muslims formed the largest group in Jerusalem until the mid-nineteenth century.{#cite_ref-186}

Between 1838 and 1876, a number of estimates exist which conflict as to whether Jews or Muslims were the largest group during this period, and between 1882 and 1922 estimates conflict as to exactly when Jews became an absolute majority of the population.  

### Current demographics {#Current_demographics}

In December 2007, Jerusalem had a population of 747,600---63.7% were Jewish, 33.1% Muslim, and 2% Christian.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-CBS2008-188)^{#cite_ref-CBS2008_188-0}

According to a study published in 2000, the percentage of Jews in the city's population had been decreasing; this was attributed to a higher Muslim [birth rate](/wiki/Birth_rate "Birth rate"), and Jewish residents leaving. The study also found that about nine percent of the Old City's 32,488 people were Jews.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-189)^ Of the Jewish population, 200,000 live in East Jerusalem settlements which are considered illegal under international law.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

In 2005, 2,850 new immigrants settled in Jerusalem, mostly from the United States, France and the former [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"). In terms of the local population, the number of outgoing residents exceeds the number of incoming residents. In 2005, 16,000 left Jerusalem and only 10,000 moved in.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ Nevertheless, the population of Jerusalem continues to rise due to the high birth rate, especially in the [Haredi Jewish](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism "Haredi Judaism") and [Arab](/wiki/Arab_people "Arab people") communities. Consequently, the [total fertility rate](/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total fertility rate") in Jerusalem (4.02) is higher than in Tel Aviv (1.98) and well above the national average of 2.90. The average size of Jerusalem's 180,000 households is 3.8 people.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^{#cite_ref-cbs_191-1}

In 2005, the total population grew by 13,000 (1.8%)---similar to the Israeli national average, but the religious and ethnic composition is shifting. While 31% of the Jewish population is made up of children below the age fifteen, the figure for the Arab population is 42%.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^{#cite_ref-cbs_191-2}

In 1967, Jews accounted for 74 percent of the population, while the figure for 2006 is down nine percent.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-192)^ Possible factors are the high cost of housing, fewer job opportunities and the increasingly religious character of the city, although proportionally, young [Haredim](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism "Haredi Judaism") are leaving in higher numbers.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The percentage of secular Jews, or those who 'wear their faith lightly' is dropping, with some 20,000 leaving the city over the past seven years (2012). They now number 31% of the population, the same percentage as the rising Haredi population.{#cite_ref-192}

In 2010, 61% of all Jewish children in Jerusalem studied in Haredi (Ultra-Orthodox) schools. This correlates with the high number of children in Haredi families.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-193)^{#cite_ref-193}

While some secular Jews leave Jerusalem for its relative lack of development and religious and political tensions, Jerusalem-born Palestinians cannot leave Jerusalem, or they lose their right to live in the city. Palestinians with a "Jerusalem resident status" are entitled to the subsidized healthcare and social security benefits Israel provides to its citizens, and have the right to vote in municipal elections, but not to be voted in municipal elections, or to vote in national elections. Arabs in Jerusalem can send their children to Israeli-run schools, although not every neighbourhood has one, and universities. Israeli doctors and highly regarded hospitals such as [Hadassah Medical Centre](/wiki/Hadassah_Medical_Center "Hadassah Medical Center") are available to residents.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-194)^{#cite_ref-194}

Demographics and the Jewish-Arab population divide play a major role in the dispute over Jerusalem. In 1998, the [Jerusalem Development Authority](/wiki/Jerusalem_Development_Authority "Jerusalem Development Authority") expanded city limits to the west to include more areas heavily populated with Jews.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-laub2006-18)^{#cite_ref-laub2006_18-1}

Within the past few years, there has been a steady increase in the Jewish birthrate and a steady decrease in the Arab birthrate. In May 2012, it was reported that the Jewish birthrate had overtaken the Arab birthrate. The city's birthrate stands about 4.2 children per Jewish family and 3.9 children per Arab family.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-195)^^[\[190\]](#cite_note-196)^ In addition, increasing numbers of Jewish immigrants chose to settle in Jerusalem. In the last few years, thousands of Palestinians have moved to previously fully Jewish neighbourhoods of East Jerusalem, built after the 1967 Six-Day War. In 2007, 1,300 Palestinians lived in the previously exclusively Jewish neighbourhood of [Pisgat Ze'ev](/wiki/Pisgat_Ze%27ev "Pisgat Ze'ev") and constituted three percent of the population in [Neve Ya'akov](/wiki/Neve_Ya%27akov "Neve Ya'akov"). In the [French Hill](/wiki/French_Hill_(neighborhood) "French Hill (neighborhood)") neighbourhood, Palestinians today constitute one-sixth of the overall population.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-197)^{#cite_ref-197}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Jerusalem_vista.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_vista.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_vista.jpg) [Sheikh Jarrah](/wiki/Sheikh_Jarrah "Sheikh Jarrah"), a predominantly Arab neighbourhood on the road to [Mount Scopus](/wiki/Mount_Scopus "Mount Scopus")

At the end of 2008, the population of East Jerusalem was 456,300, comprising 60% of Jerusalem's residents. Of these, 195,500 (43%) were Jews, (comprising 40% of the Jewish population of Jerusalem as a whole), and 260,800 (57%) were Muslim (comprising 98% of the Muslim population of Jerusalem).^[\[192\]](#cite_note-198)^ In 2008, the [Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics](/wiki/Palestinian_Central_Bureau_of_Statistics "Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics") reported the number of Palestinians living in East Jerusalem was 208,000 according to a recently completed census.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-grow-199)^{#cite_ref-grow_199-0}

Jerusalem's Jewish population is overwhelmingly religious. Only 18% of Jewish residents are secular. In addition, [Haredi Jews](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism "Haredi Judaism") comprise 35% of the city's adult Jewish population. In a phenomenon seen rarely around the world, the percentage of Jewish women who work, 81%, exceeds the percentage of Jewish men who work, 70%.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}

Jerusalem had a population of 804,400 in 2011, of which Jews comprised 499,400 (62.1%), Muslims 281,100 (34.9%), Christians 14,700 (1.8%), and 9,000 (1.1%) were not classified by religion.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-PopRel-20)^{#cite_ref-PopRel_20-1}

Jerusalem had a population of 882,700 in 2016, of which Jews comprised 536,600 (60.8%), Muslims 319,800 (36.2%), Christians 15,800 (1.8%), and 10,300 unclassified (1.2%).^[\[16\]](#cite_note-PopRel-20)^{#cite_ref-PopRel_20-2}

Jerusalem had a population of 951,100 in 2020, of which [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews") comprised 570,100 (59.9%), [Muslims](/wiki/Muslims "Muslims") 353.800 (37.2%), [Christians](/wiki/Christians "Christians") 16.300 (1.7%), and 10,800 unclassified (1.1%).^[\[16\]](#cite_note-PopRel-20)^{#cite_ref-PopRel_20-3}

According to [Peace Now](/wiki/Peace_Now "Peace Now"), approvals for building in Israeli settlements in [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem") have expanded by 60% under Donald Trump's term as U.S. president.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-201)^ Since 1991, Palestinians, who make up the majority of the residents in East Jerusalem, have only received 30% of the building permits.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-202)^{#cite_ref-202}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/220px-Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg)](/wiki/File:Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian,_Jerusalem.jpg) Sign in [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language") in the [Armenian Quarter](/wiki/Armenian_Quarter "Armenian Quarter")  

### Urban planning issues {#Urban_planning_issues}

Critics of efforts to promote a Jewish majority in Jerusalem say that government planning policies are motivated by demographic considerations and seek to limit Arab construction while promoting Jewish construction.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-203)^ According to a [World Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") report, the number of recorded building violations between 1996 and 2000 was four and half times higher in Jewish neighbourhoods but four times fewer demolition orders were issued in West Jerusalem than in East Jerusalem; Arabs in Jerusalem were less likely to receive construction permits than Jews, and "the authorities are much more likely to take action against Palestinian violators" than Jewish violators of the permit process.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-worldbank-204)^ In recent years, private Jewish foundations have received permission from the government to develop projects on disputed lands, such as the [City of David archaeological site](/wiki/City_of_David_(archaeological_site) "City of David (archaeological site)") in the 60% Arab neighbourhood of [Silwan](/wiki/Silwan "Silwan") (adjacent to the Old City),^[\[199\]](#cite_note-205)^ and the [Museum of Tolerance](/wiki/Museum_of_Tolerance_Jerusalem "Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem") on Mamilla Cemetery (adjacent to Zion Square).^[\[198\]](#cite_note-worldbank-204)^^[\[200\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}  

Religious significance {#Religious_significance}
------------------------------------------------

Main article: [Religious significance of Jerusalem](/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem "Religious significance of Jerusalem")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG/220px-THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG)](/wiki/File:THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG) The [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem) "Old City (Jerusalem)") is home to many sites of seminal [religious importance](/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem "Religious significance of Jerusalem") for the three major [Abrahamic religions](/wiki/Abrahamic_religions "Abrahamic religions")---[Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), and [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam").

Jerusalem has been sacred to Judaism for roughly 3000 years, to Christianity for around 2000 years, and to Islam for approximately 1400 years. The 2000 Statistical Yearbook of Jerusalem lists 1204 synagogues, 158 churches, and 73 mosques within the city.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-207)^ Despite efforts to maintain peaceful religious coexistence, some sites, such as the Temple Mount, have been a continuous source of friction and controversy. The [Temple Mount](/wiki/Temple_Mount "Temple Mount") is the holiest spot in [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") and the third holiest site in Islam. Jews venerate it as the site of the two former [Temples](/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem "Temple in Jerusalem") and [Muslims](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") believe that [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam "Muhammad in Islam") was transported from the [Great Mosque of Mecca](/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca "Great Mosque of Mecca") to this location during the [Night Journey](/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj "Isra and Mi'raj").{#cite_ref-207}  

### Judaism {#Judaism}

Further information: [Jerusalem in Judaism](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Judaism "Jerusalem in Judaism")

Jerusalem has been the [holiest city](/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities "Four Holy Cities") in Judaism and the ancestral and spiritual homeland of the Jewish people since King David proclaimed it his capital in the 10th century BCE.^[\[note 5\]](#cite_note-bible-david-22)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-1000BCE-25)^ Without counting its other names, Jerusalem appears in the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible") 669 times.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-208)^ The first section, the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") (Pentateuch), only mentions [Moriah](/wiki/Moriah "Moriah"), but in later parts of the Bible, the city is mentioned explicitly.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-209)^ The Temple Mount, which was the site of Solomon's Temple and the Second Temple, is the holiest site in Judaism and the place Jews turn towards during prayer.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-210)^^[\[205\]](#cite_note-211)^ The Western Wall, a remnant of the wall surrounding the Second Temple, is the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-212)^ Synagogues around the world are traditionally built with the Holy Ark facing Jerusalem,^[\[207\]](#cite_note-213)^ and Arks within Jerusalem face the [Holy of Holies](/wiki/Holy_of_Holies "Holy of Holies").^[\[208\]](#cite_note-returning-214)^ As prescribed in the [Mishna](/wiki/Mishnah "Mishnah") and codified in the *[Shulchan Aruch](/wiki/Shulchan_Aruch "Shulchan Aruch")* , daily prayers are recited while facing towards Jerusalem and the Temple Mount. Many Jews have "[Mizrach](/wiki/Mizrah "Mizrah")" plaques hung on a wall of their homes to indicate the direction of prayer.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-returning-214)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-215)^ The [Western Wall](/wiki/Western_Wall "Western Wall") is a remnant of the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second Temple") and the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray.{#cite_ref-215}  

### Christianity {#Christianity}

Further information: [Jerusalem in Christianity](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity "Jerusalem in Christianity")

Jerusalem is generally considered the cradle of Christianity.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-216)^ Christianity reveres Jerusalem for its [Old Testament](/wiki/Old_Testament "Old Testament") history, and also for its significance in the life of Jesus. According to the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament"), Jesus was brought to Jerusalem soon after his birth^[\[211\]](#cite_note-217)^ and later in his life cleansed the Second Temple.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-218)^ The [Cenacle](/wiki/Cenacle "Cenacle"), believed to be the site of Jesus' [Last Supper](/wiki/Last_Supper "Last Supper"), is located on [Mount Zion](/wiki/Mount_Zion "Mount Zion") in the same building that houses the [Tomb of King David](/wiki/David%27s_Tomb "David's Tomb").^[\[213\]](#cite_note-219)^^[\[214\]](#cite_note-220)^ Another prominent Christian site in Jerusalem is [Golgotha](/wiki/Calvary "Calvary"), the site of the [crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion "Crucifixion"). The [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") describes it as being located outside Jerusalem,^[\[215\]](#cite_note-221)^ but recent archaeological evidence suggests Golgotha is a short distance from the Old City walls, within the present-day confines of the city.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-worldwide-222)^ The land occupied by the [Church of the Holy Sepulchre](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of the Holy Sepulchre") is considered one of the top candidates for Golgotha and thus has been a Christian pilgrimage site for the past 2000 years.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-worldwide-222)^^[\[217\]](#cite_note-223)^^[\[218\]](#cite_note-224)^ The [Church of the Holy Sepulchre](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of the Holy Sepulchre") is generally considered the most important church in [Christendom](/wiki/Christendom "Christendom").^[\[219\]](#cite_note-225)^ It contains the two holiest sites in [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"): the site where [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") was [crucified](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus"), and Jesus's empty tomb, where he is believed by Christians to have been [buried](/wiki/Burial_of_Jesus "Burial of Jesus") and [resurrected](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection of Jesus").{#cite_ref-225}  

### Islam {#Islam}

Further information: [Jerusalem in Islam](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Islam "Jerusalem in Islam")  
See also: [Islamization of Jerusalem](/wiki/Islamization_of_Jerusalem "Islamization of Jerusalem")

Jerusalem is the third-holiest city in [Sunni Islam](/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-3rd-32)^ Islamic tradition holds that for approximately a year, before it was permanently switched to the [Kaaba](/wiki/Kaaba "Kaaba") in [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca"), the *[qibla](/wiki/Qibla "Qibla")* (direction of [prayer](/wiki/Salat "Salat")) for Muslims was Jerusalem.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-226)^^[\[221\]](#cite_note-227)^ The city's lasting place in Islam, however, is primarily due to [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad "Muhammad")'s [Night Journey](/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj "Isra and Mi'raj") ( 620 CE). Muslims believe that Muhammad was miraculously transported one night from the [Great Mosque of Mecca](/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca "Great Mosque of Mecca") to the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, whereupon he ascended to [Heaven](/wiki/Jannah "Jannah") to meet previous [prophets of Islam](/wiki/Prophets_of_Islam "Prophets of Islam").^[\[222\]](#cite_note-228)^^[\[223\]](#cite_note-229)^^[\[224\]](#cite_note-230)^ The first verse in the [Qur'an](/wiki/Qur%27an "Qur'an")'s [*Surat al-Isra*](/wiki/Al-Isra "Al-Isra") notes the destination of Muhammad's journey as *al-masjid al-aqṣā* ("the farthest place of prayer").^[\[225\]](#cite_note-231)^^[\[226\]](#cite_note-232)^ In the earliest days of Islam, this was understood as a reference to a site in the heavens,^[\[227\]](#cite_note-:8-233)^ however, Post-[Rashidun](/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate "Rashidun Caliphate") Islamic scholars understood it as relating to Jerusalem, and particularly to the site of the former Jewish Temple.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-234)^ The [hadith](/wiki/Hadith "Hadith"), a collection of the sayings of Muhammad, mentions that the location of the Al-Aqsa Mosque is in Jerusalem.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-235)^ The [Al-Aqsa Mosque](/wiki/Qibli_Mosque "Qibli Mosque"), originally named after the wider compound it sits within,^[\[230\]](#cite_note-236)^ was built on the Temple Mount under the Umayyad Caliph [Al-Walid](/wiki/Al-Walid_ibn_Abd_al-Malik "Al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik") several decades after Muhammad's death to commemorate the place from which Muslims believe he had ascended to Heaven.^[\[231\]](#cite_note-237)^{#cite_ref-237}
