[Al-Aqsa Mosque](/wiki/Qibli_Mosque "Qibli Mosque"), on the Temple Mount ([Haram al-Sharif](/wiki/Haram_al-Sharif "Haram al-Sharif") or [Al-Aqsa compound](/wiki/Al-Aqsa_compound "Al-Aqsa compound"))  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG)](/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG) [Bank of Israel](/wiki/Bank_of_Israel "Bank of Israel")

Historically, Jerusalem's economy was supported almost exclusively by religious pilgrims, as it was far from the major ports of [Jaffa](/wiki/Jaffa "Jaffa") and [Gaza](/wiki/Gaza_City "Gaza City").^[\[232\]](#cite_note-politics67-238)^ Jerusalem's religious and cultural landmarks today remain the top draw for foreign visitors, with the majority of tourists visiting the Western Wall and the [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem) "Old City (Jerusalem)").^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ In 2010, Jerusalem was named the top leisure travel city in Africa and the Middle East by [*Travel + Leisure magazine*](/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure "Travel + Leisure").^[\[233\]](#cite_note-239)^ in 2013, 75% of the 3.5 million tourists to Israel visited Jerusalem.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Hotzvimview.jpg/220px-Hotzvimview.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hotzvimview.jpg) [Har Hotzvim](/wiki/Har_Hotzvim "Har Hotzvim") high-tech park

Since the establishment of the State of Israel, the national government has remained a major player in Jerusalem's economy. The government, centred in Jerusalem, generates a large number of jobs, and offers subsidies and incentives for new business initiatives and start-ups.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-politics67-238)^ Although Tel Aviv remains Israel's financial centre, a growing number of [high tech](/wiki/High_tech "High tech") companies are moving to Jerusalem, providing 12,000 jobs in 2006.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-241)^ Northern Jerusalem's [Har Hotzvim](/wiki/Har_Hotzvim "Har Hotzvim") industrial park and the [Jerusalem Technology Park](/wiki/Jerusalem_Technology_Park "Jerusalem Technology Park") in south Jerusalem are home to large [Research and Development](/wiki/Research_and_Development "Research and Development") centres of international tech companies, among them [Intel](/wiki/Intel_Corporation "Intel Corporation"), [Cisco Systems](/wiki/Cisco_Systems "Cisco Systems"), [Teva Pharmaceutical Industries](/wiki/Teva_Pharmaceutical_Industries "Teva Pharmaceutical Industries"), [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM"), [Mobileye](/wiki/Mobileye "Mobileye"), [Johnson \& Johnson](/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson "Johnson & Johnson"), [Medtronic](/wiki/Medtronic "Medtronic") and more.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-242)^ In April 2015, [Time Magazine](/wiki/Time_Magazine "Time Magazine") picked Jerusalem as one of the five emerging tech hubs in the world, proclaiming that "The city has become a flourishing centre for biomed, cleantech, Internet/mobile startups, accelerators, investors and supporting service providers."^[\[237\]](#cite_note-243)^{#cite_ref-243}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Israel,_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_(5172398236).jpg) [Mamilla Mall](/wiki/Mamilla_Mall "Mamilla Mall") adorned with upscale shops stands just outside the Old City Walls. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/MalhaMallApr192023_01.jpg/220px-MalhaMallApr192023_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:MalhaMallApr192023_01.jpg) [Malha Mall](/wiki/Malha_Mall "Malha Mall")

Higher than average percentages are employed in education (17.9% vs. 12.7%); health and welfare (12.6% vs. 10.7%); community and social services (6.4% vs. 4.7%); hotels and restaurants (6.1% vs. 4.7%); and public administration (8.2% vs. 4.7%).^[\[238\]](#cite_note-244)^ During the [British Mandate](/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine "Mandatory Palestine"), a law was passed requiring all buildings to be constructed of [Jerusalem stone](/wiki/Jerusalem_stone "Jerusalem stone") in order to preserve the unique historic and aesthetic character of the city.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-BIUmandate-245)^ Complementing this building code, which is still in force, is the discouragement of [heavy industry](/wiki/Heavy_industry "Heavy industry") in Jerusalem; only about 2.2% of Jerusalem's land is zoned for "industry and infrastructure". By comparison, the percentage of land in Tel Aviv zoned for industry and infrastructure is twice as high, and in Haifa, seven times as high.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ Only 8.5% of the [Jerusalem District](/wiki/Jerusalem_District "Jerusalem District") work force is employed in the manufacturing sector, which is half the national average (15.8%).{#cite_ref-cbs_191-4}

Although many statistics indicate economic growth in the city, since 1967, East Jerusalem has lagged behind the development of West Jerusalem.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-politics67-238)^ Nevertheless, the percentage of households with employed persons is higher for Arab households (76.1%) than for Jewish households (66.8%). The unemployment rate in Jerusalem (8.3%) is slightly better than the national average (9.0%), although the civilian [labour force](/wiki/Labor_force "Labor force") accounted for less than half of all persons fifteen years or older---lower in comparison to that of Tel Aviv (58.0%) and [Haifa](/wiki/Haifa "Haifa") (52.4%).^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ Poverty remains a problem in the city as 37% of the families in Jerusalem lived in 2011 below the poverty line. According to a report by the [Association for Civil Rights in Israel](/wiki/Association_for_Civil_Rights_in_Israel "Association for Civil Rights in Israel") (ACRI), 78% of Arabs in Jerusalem lived in poverty in 2012, up from 64% in 2006. While the ACRI attributes the increase to the lack of employment opportunities, infrastructure and a worsening educational system, [Ir Amim](/wiki/Ir_Amim "Ir Amim") blames the legal status of Palestinians in Jerusalem.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-Hasson-246)^{#cite_ref-Hasson_246-0}

The increasing number of educated Palestinians in Jerusalem has brought about positive economic changes.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-247)^ Through reforms and initiatives in sectors like technology, tourism, trade, and infrastructure, they have helped drive economic growth, create jobs, and improve living conditions in the city.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-248)^^[\[243\]](#cite_note-249)^ Various joint summits between Israeli and Palestinian entrepreneurs have been held in the city.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-250)^ [Palestine Investment Fund](/wiki/Palestine_Investment_Fund "Palestine Investment Fund") have proposed various projects in Jerusalem.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-251)^^[\[246\]](#cite_note-252)^ Palestinian industrialist [Bashar Masri](/wiki/Bashar_Masri "Bashar Masri") sought to make heavy investments in the city.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-253)^ PA controlled industrial areas are located outskirts of Jerusalem, primarily in [Bir Nabala](/wiki/Bir_Nabala "Bir Nabala"), [Abu Dis](/wiki/Abu_Dis "Abu Dis") and [Eizariya](/wiki/Eizariya "Eizariya"), engaging in manufacture of tires, food products and concretes.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-254)^{#cite_ref-254}

High-tech industry is emerged among Palestinian society of Jerusalem.^[\[249\]](#cite_note-255)^^[\[250\]](#cite_note-256)^ In 2023, Israel opened a technology park in East Jerusalem, known as EasTech. Local Palestinian engineers are employed in the complex by multinational companies, some of which includes [AT\&T](/wiki/AT%26T "AT&T"), [Natural Intelligence](/w/index.php?title=Natural_Intelligence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Natural Intelligence (page does not exist)"), [Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), [Unity](/wiki/Unity_(game_engine) "Unity (game engine)") and [Synamedia](/wiki/Synamedia "Synamedia"). Station J, an innovation hub is located in Sheikh Jarrah, which is yet another tech hub for Palestinians in the city. Hani Alami, a Jerusalem-based Palestinian entrepreneur has set up a start-+up accelerator.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-257)^ As a part of [Israeli--Palestinian economic peace efforts](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_economic_peace_efforts "Israeli–Palestinian economic peace efforts"), interaction between Israeli and Palestinian business community, also contributes in growth of Palestinian IT sector in the city.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-258)^^[\[253\]](#cite_note-259)^{#cite_ref-259}  

Urban structure {#Urban_structure}
----------------------------------

### High-rise construction {#High-rise_construction}

Jerusalem has traditionally had a low-rise skyline. About 18 tall buildings were built at different times in the downtown area when there was no clear policy over the matter. One of them, Holyland Tower 1, Jerusalem's tallest building, is a [skyscraper](/wiki/Skyscraper "Skyscraper") by international standards, rising 32 stories. Holyland Tower 2, which has been approved for construction, will reach the same height.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-260)^^[\[255\]](#cite_note-261)^{#cite_ref-261}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg) Holyland Tower, Jerusalem's tallest building

A new master plan for the city will see many high-rise buildings, including skyscrapers, built in certain, designated areas of downtown Jerusalem. Under the plan, towers will line [Jaffa Road](/wiki/Jaffa_Road "Jaffa Road") and [King George Street](/wiki/King_George_Street_(Jerusalem) "King George Street (Jerusalem)"). One of the proposed towers along King George Street, the Migdal Merkaz HaYekum, is planned as a 65-story building, which would make it one of the tallest buildings in Israel. At the entrance to the city, near the [Jerusalem Chords Bridge](/wiki/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge "Jerusalem Chords Bridge") and the [Central Bus Station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station "Jerusalem Central Bus Station"), twelve towers rising between 24 and 33 stories will be built, as part of a complex that will also include an open square and an [underground train station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Binyanei_HaUma_Railway_Station "Jerusalem Binyanei HaUma Railway Station") serving a new express line between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, and will be connected by bridges and tunnels. Eleven of the skyscrapers will be either office or apartment buildings, and one will be a 2,000-room hotel. The complex is expected to attract many businesses from Tel Aviv, and become the city's main business hub. In addition, a complex for the city's courts and the prosecutor's office will be built, as well as new buildings for Central Zionist Archives and [Israel State Archives](/wiki/Israel_State_Archives "Israel State Archives").^[\[256\]](#cite_note-262)^^[\[257\]](#cite_note-263)^^[\[258\]](#cite_note-264)^ The skyscrapers built throughout the city are expected to contain public space, shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, and it has been speculated that this may lead to a revitalization of downtown Jerusalem.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-265)^^[\[260\]](#cite_note-266)^ In August 2015, the city council approved construction of a 344-foot pyramid-shaped skyscraper designed by [Daniel Libeskind](/wiki/Daniel_Libeskind "Daniel Libeskind") and Yigal Levi, in place of a rejected previous design by Libeskind; it is set to break ground by 2019.^[\[261\]](#cite_note-267)^{#cite_ref-267}  

### New projects in Jerusalem {#New_projects_in_Jerusalem}

In 2021, [Bashar Masri](/wiki/Bashar_Masri "Bashar Masri") announced and launched "Lana", a massive mix-used project in [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem"), which is located in the neighborhood of [Beit Hanina](/wiki/Beit_Hanina "Beit Hanina"). The project is in a partnership between Massar International and the [Orthodox Church of Jerusalem](/wiki/Orthodox_Church_of_Jerusalem "Orthodox Church of Jerusalem"). It features 400 residential apartments along with a vibrant commercial center that hosts well-known global brands, [cinemas](/wiki/Cinemas "Cinemas"), [restaurants](/wiki/Restaurants "Restaurants"), [cafes](/wiki/Cafes "Cafes"), and [offices](/wiki/Offices "Offices"). The project also includes modern educational facilities, such as a school and a [kindergarten](/wiki/Kindergarten "Kindergarten"), catering to the needs of residents. In addition to its focus on residential and commercial aspects, the Lana project emphasizes the improvement of infrastructure within the project and its surroundings. This involves the construction of three to four floors of underground parking to accommodate the residents' vehicles conveniently. Furthermore, there is a comprehensive plan to expand the road network surrounding the project, ensuring smooth transportation and accessibility for both residents and visitors. It is situated just 15 minutes away from the historic [Old City of Jerusalem](/wiki/Old_City_of_Jerusalem "Old City of Jerusalem").^[\[262\]](#cite_note-268)^{#cite_ref-268}  

Transportation {#Transportation}
--------------------------------

Main article: [Transport in Jerusalem](/wiki/Transport_in_Jerusalem "Transport in Jerusalem")  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG/220px-Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG) [Jerusalem Chords Bridge](/wiki/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge "Jerusalem Chords Bridge")

Jerusalem is served by highly developed communication infrastructures, making it a leading logistics hub for Israel.

The [Jerusalem Central Bus Station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station "Jerusalem Central Bus Station"), located on [Jaffa Road](/wiki/Jaffa_Road "Jaffa Road"), is the busiest bus station in Israel. It is served by [Egged Bus Cooperative](/wiki/Egged_(company) "Egged (company)"), which is the second-largest bus company in the world,^[\[263\]](#cite_note-269)^ The [Dan](/wiki/Dan_Bus_Company "Dan Bus Company") serves the [Bnei Brak](/wiki/Bnei_Brak "Bnei Brak")-Jerusalem route along with Egged, and [Superbus](/wiki/Superbus_(company) "Superbus (company)") serves the routes between Jerusalem, [Modi'in Illit](/wiki/Modi%27in_Illit "Modi'in Illit"), and [Modi'in-Maccabim-Re'ut](/wiki/Modi%27in-Maccabim-Re%27ut "Modi'in-Maccabim-Re'ut"). The companies operate from [Jerusalem Central Bus Station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station "Jerusalem Central Bus Station"). Arab neighbourhoods in East Jerusalem and routes between Jerusalem and locations in the [West Bank](/wiki/West_Bank "West Bank") are served by the [East Jerusalem Central Bus Station](/wiki/East_Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station "East Jerusalem Central Bus Station"), a transportation hub located near the Old City's [Damascus Gate](/wiki/Damascus_Gate "Damascus Gate").{#cite_ref-269}  

### Railway {#Railway}

The [Jerusalem Light Rail](/wiki/Jerusalem_Light_Rail "Jerusalem Light Rail") initiated service in August 2011. According to plans, the first rail line will be capable of transporting an estimated 200,000 people daily, and has 23 stops. The route is from Pisgat Ze'ev in the north via the Old City and city centre to Mt. Herzl in the south.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg/220px-JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:JLR_26,_Jaffa_Street,_2019_(01).jpg) [Light Rail](/wiki/Jerusalem_Light_Rail "Jerusalem Light Rail") tram on [Jaffa Road](/wiki/Jaffa_Road "Jaffa Road")

A [high-speed rail line](/wiki/High-speed_railway_to_Jerusalem "High-speed railway to Jerusalem") connecting Tel Aviv to Jerusalem became partially operational in 2018 and was completed in 2019.^[\[264\]](#cite_note-270)^ Its terminus is at the [new underground station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Binyanei_HaUma_Railway_Station "Jerusalem Binyanei HaUma Railway Station") (80 m or 262 ft deep) serving the [International Convention Centre](/wiki/International_Convention_Center_(Jerusalem) "International Convention Center (Jerusalem)") and the Central Bus Station,^[\[265\]](#cite_note-271)^ and is planned to be extended eventually to [Malha station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Malha_Railway_Station "Jerusalem Malha Railway Station"). [Israel Railways](/wiki/Israel_Railways "Israel Railways") operated train services to [Malha train station](/wiki/Jerusalem_Malha_Railway_Station "Jerusalem Malha Railway Station") from Tel Aviv via [Beit Shemesh](/wiki/Beit_Shemesh "Beit Shemesh"), but this service was discontinued in 2020.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-272)^^[\[267\]](#cite_note-273)^^[\[268\]](#cite_note-274)^{#cite_ref-274}

[Begin Expressway](/wiki/Highway_50_(Israel) "Highway 50 (Israel)") is one of Jerusalem's major north--south thoroughfares; it runs on the western side of the city, merging in the north with [Route 443](/wiki/Route_443_(Israel) "Route 443 (Israel)"), which continues toward Tel Aviv. [Route 60](/wiki/Highway_60_(Israel) "Highway 60 (Israel)") runs through the centre of the city near the [Green Line](/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel) "Green Line (Israel)") between East and West Jerusalem. Construction is progressing on parts of a 35 km (22 mi) [ring road](/wiki/Beltway "Beltway") around the city, fostering faster connection between the suburbs.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-rings-275)^^[\[270\]](#cite_note-276)^ The eastern half of the project was conceptualized decades ago, but reaction to the proposed highway is still mixed.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-rings-275)^{#cite_ref-rings_275-1}  

### Airport {#Airport}

In the past, Jerusalem was also served by the local [Jerusalem International Airport](/wiki/Atarot_Airport "Atarot Airport"), locally known as Atarot Airport. It was the first airport built in the British Mandate of Palestine. Palestinians considered the Atarot Airport as a "symbol of Palestinian sovereignty".^[\[271\]](#cite_note-277)^ The airport falls beyond Green Line. After 1948 war, it came under control of Jordan. Following the Six Day War of 1967, the airport came under control of Israel.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-278)^ With increase of violence in the [second intifada](/wiki/Second_intifada "Second intifada"), Atarot Airport ceased operation in 2000. Today Jerusalem is served by [Ben Gurion Airport](/wiki/Ben_Gurion_Airport "Ben Gurion Airport"), some 50 km (30 mi) northwest of the Jerusalem, on the route to Tel Aviv. The [Tel Aviv--Jerusalem railway](/wiki/Tel_Aviv%E2%80%93Jerusalem_railway "Tel Aviv–Jerusalem railway") runs non-stop from [Jerusalem--Yitzhak Navon railway station](/wiki/Jerusalem%E2%80%93Yitzhak_Navon_railway_station "Jerusalem–Yitzhak Navon railway station") to the airport and began operation in 2018.^[\[273\]](#cite_note-279)^{#cite_ref-279}

Australian businessman [Kevin Bermeister](/wiki/Kevin_Bermeister "Kevin Bermeister") proposed a masterplan of Jerusalem, which also includes the development of an airport for Jerusalem in the [Jordan Valley](/wiki/Jordan_Valley "Jordan Valley"), near [Jericho](/wiki/Jericho "Jericho").^[\[274\]](#cite_note-280)^ The airport is sought to be a joint Israeli-Palestinian airport. Palestinian Prime Minister [Mohammad Shtayyeh](/wiki/Mohammad_Shtayyeh "Mohammad Shtayyeh") have also appealed to Israeli authorities to redevelop the airport.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-281)^ In 2021, the Israeli government planned to redevelop Atarot Airport as a joint Israeli--Palestinian airport.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-282)^ The new Atarot Airport will include two separate Israeli and Palestinian terminals.{#cite_ref-282}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

### Universities {#Universities}

Jerusalem is home to several prestigious universities offering courses in [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"), [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") and English.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg/220px-HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg)](/wiki/File:HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg) [Hebrew University of Jerusalem](/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem "Hebrew University of Jerusalem"), [Mount Scopus](/wiki/Mount_Scopus "Mount Scopus") campus

Founded in 1925, the [Hebrew University of Jerusalem](/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem "Hebrew University of Jerusalem") has been ranked among the top 100 schools in the world.^[\[277\]](#cite_note-283)^ The Board of Governors has included such prominent Jewish intellectuals as [Albert Einstein](/wiki/Albert_Einstein "Albert Einstein") and [Sigmund Freud](/wiki/Sigmund_Freud "Sigmund Freud").^[\[278\]](#cite_note-hujiHistory-284)^ The university has produced several [Nobel](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") laureates; recent winners associated with Hebrew University include [Avram Hershko](/wiki/Avram_Hershko "Avram Hershko"),^[\[279\]](#cite_note-285)^ [David Gross](/wiki/David_Gross "David Gross"),^[\[280\]](#cite_note-286)^ and [Daniel Kahneman](/wiki/Daniel_Kahneman "Daniel Kahneman").^[\[281\]](#cite_note-287)^ One of the university's major assets is the [Jewish National and University Library](/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel "National Library of Israel"), which houses over five million books.^[\[282\]](#cite_note-288)^ The library opened in 1892, over three decades before the university was established, and is one of the world's largest repositories of books on Jewish subjects. Today it is both the central library of the university and the national library of Israel.^[\[283\]](#cite_note-289)^ The Hebrew University operates three campuses in Jerusalem, on Mount Scopus, on [Giv'at Ram](/wiki/Givat_Ram "Givat Ram") and a medical campus at the [Hadassah Ein Kerem hospital](/wiki/Hadassah_Medical_Center "Hadassah Medical Center"). The [Academy of the Hebrew Language](/wiki/Academy_of_the_Hebrew_Language "Academy of the Hebrew Language") are located in the Hebrew university in Givat Ram and the [Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities](/wiki/Israel_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Humanities "Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities") located near the [Presidents House](/wiki/Beit_HaNassi "Beit HaNassi").{#cite_ref-289}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg/220px-Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg) [Hebron Yeshiva](/wiki/Hebron_Yeshiva "Hebron Yeshiva") in [Givat Mordechai](/wiki/Givat_Mordechai "Givat Mordechai") neighbourhood

The [Jerusalem College of Technology](/wiki/Jerusalem_College_of_Technology "Jerusalem College of Technology"), founded in 1969, combines training in engineering and other high-tech industries with a Jewish studies programme.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-290)^ It is one of many schools in Jerusalem, from elementary school and up, that combine secular and religious studies. Numerous religious educational institutions and [*Yeshivot*](/wiki/Yeshiva "Yeshiva"), including some of the most prestigious yeshivas, among them the [Brisk](/wiki/Brisk_yeshiva "Brisk yeshiva"), [Chevron](/wiki/Chevron_yeshiva "Chevron yeshiva"), [Midrash Shmuel](/wiki/Midrash_Shmuel_Yeshiva "Midrash Shmuel Yeshiva") and [Mir](/wiki/Mir_yeshiva_(Jerusalem) "Mir yeshiva (Jerusalem)"), are based in the city, with the Mir Yeshiva claiming to be the largest.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-291)^ There were nearly 8,000 twelfth-grade students in Hebrew-language schools during the 2003--2004 school year.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ However, due to the large portion of students in [Haredi Jewish](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism "Haredi Judaism") frameworks, only fifty-five percent of twelfth graders took [matriculation](/wiki/Matriculation "Matriculation") exams (*[Bagrut](/wiki/Bagrut "Bagrut")* ) and only thirty-seven percent were eligible to graduate. Unlike [public schools](/wiki/Public_school_(government_funded) "Public school (government funded)"), many Haredi schools do not prepare students to take standardized tests.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-cbs-191)^ To attract more university students to Jerusalem, the city has begun to offer a special package of financial incentives and housing subsidies to students who rent apartments in downtown Jerusalem.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-292)^{#cite_ref-292}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Abu_jihad.jpg/220px-Abu_jihad.jpg)](/wiki/File:Abu_jihad.jpg) Inside [Abu Jihad Museum](/wiki/Abu_Jihad "Abu Jihad") of [Al-Quds University](/wiki/Al-Quds_University "Al-Quds University")

[Al-Quds University](/wiki/Al-Quds_University "Al-Quds University") was established in 1984^[\[287\]](#cite_note-quds1-293)^ to serve as a flagship university for the Arab and Palestinian peoples.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ It describes itself as the "only Arab university in Jerusalem".^[\[288\]](#cite_note-294)^ [Bard College](/wiki/Bard_College "Bard College") of Annandale-on-Hudson, New York and Al-Quds University agreed to open a joint college in a building originally built to house the [Palestinian Legislative Council](/wiki/Palestinian_Legislative_Council "Palestinian Legislative Council") and [Yasser Arafat](/wiki/Yasser_Arafat "Yasser Arafat")'s office. The college gives [Master of Arts in Teaching](/wiki/Master_of_Arts_in_Teaching "Master of Arts in Teaching") degrees.^[\[289\]](#cite_note-Kalman-295)^ Al-Quds University resides southeast of the city proper on a 190,000 m^2^ (47-acre) [Abu Dis](/wiki/Abu_Dis "Abu Dis") campus.^[\[287\]](#cite_note-quds1-293)^ Other campuses of AQU are located within city limits of Jerusalem. A campus of university in [Sheikh Jarrah](/wiki/Sheikh_Jarrah "Sheikh Jarrah"), which is one of the oldest faculties, is known as Hind Al Husseini College for Arts.^[\[290\]](#cite_note-296)^ It was named after [Hind al-Husseini](/wiki/Hind_al-Husseini "Hind al-Husseini"), a Palestinian activists known for rescuing orphaned survivors of [Deir Yassin massacre](/wiki/Deir_Yassin_massacre "Deir Yassin massacre") and giving them shelter in a palace of her grandfather, which was converted into an orphanage and later a college, which is a part today's Al Quds University.^[\[291\]](#cite_note-297)^ A joint campus of AQU and Bard College is located in [Beit Hanina](/wiki/Beit_Hanina "Beit Hanina"). [Bayt Mal Al Qods Acharif Agency](/wiki/Bayt_Mal_Al_Qods_Acharif_Agency "Bayt Mal Al Qods Acharif Agency"), a Moroccan organization is constructing a new campus in same neighborhood.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-298)^{#cite_ref-298}

Other institutions of higher learning in Jerusalem are the [Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance](/wiki/Jerusalem_Academy_of_Music_and_Dance "Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance")^[\[293\]](#cite_note-299)^ and [Bezalel Academy of Art and Design](/wiki/Bezalel_Academy_of_Arts_and_Design "Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design"),^[\[294\]](#cite_note-300)^^[\[295\]](#cite_note-301)^ whose buildings are located on the campuses of the Hebrew University.{#cite_ref-301}  

### Arab schools {#Arab_schools}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Du-leshoni-2.jpg/220px-Du-leshoni-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Du-leshoni-2.jpg) [Hand in Hand](/wiki/Hand_in_Hand:_Center_for_Jewish-Arab_Education_in_Israel "Hand in Hand: Center for Jewish-Arab Education in Israel"), a bilingual Jewish-Arab school in Jerusalem

Israel's public schools for Arabs in Jerusalem and other parts of the country have been criticized for offering a lower quality education than those catering to Israeli Jewish students.^[\[296\]](#cite_note-HumanRights-302)^ While many schools in the heavily Arab East Jerusalem are filled to capacity and there have been complaints of overcrowding, the Jerusalem Municipality is building over a dozen new schools in the city's Arab neighbourhoods.^[\[297\]](#cite_note-303)^ Schools in [Ras el-Amud](/wiki/Ras_al-Amud "Ras al-Amud") and [Umm Lison](/w/index.php?title=Umm_Lison&action=edit&redlink=1 "Umm Lison (page does not exist)") opened in 2008.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-lis-304)^ In March 2007, the Israeli government approved a five-year plan to build 8,000 new classrooms in the city, 40 percent in the Arab sector and 28 percent in the Haredi sector. A budget of 4.6 billion shekels was allocated for this project.^[\[299\]](#cite_note-305)^ In 2008, Jewish British philanthropists donated $3 million for the construction of schools for Arabs in East Jerusalem.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-lis-304)^ Arab high school students take the *[Bagrut](/wiki/Bagrut "Bagrut")* matriculation exams, so that much of their curriculum parallels that of other Israeli high schools and includes certain Jewish subjects.^[\[296\]](#cite_note-HumanRights-302)^{#cite_ref-HumanRights_302-1}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Jerusalem_Schrein_des_Buches_BW_1.JPG/220px-Jerusalem_Schrein_des_Buches_BW_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Schrein_des_Buches_BW_1.JPG) The [Shrine of the Book](/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book "Shrine of the Book"), housing the [Dead Sea Scrolls](/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls "Dead Sea Scrolls"), at the [Israel Museum](/wiki/Israel_Museum "Israel Museum")

Although Jerusalem is known primarily for its [religious significance](/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem "Religious significance of Jerusalem"), the city is also home to many artistic and cultural venues. The [Israel Museum](/wiki/Israel_Museum "Israel Museum") attracts nearly one million visitors a year, approximately one-third of them tourists.^[\[300\]](#cite_note-IMJ-306)^ The 8 ha (20-acre) museum complex comprises several buildings featuring special exhibits and extensive collections of [Judaica](/wiki/Jewish_ceremonial_art "Jewish ceremonial art"), archaeological findings, and Israeli and European art. The [Dead Sea scrolls](/wiki/Dead_Sea_scrolls "Dead Sea scrolls"), discovered in the mid-20th century in the [Qumran Caves](/wiki/Qumran_Caves "Qumran Caves") near the Dead Sea, are housed in the Museum's [Shrine of the Book](/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book "Shrine of the Book").^[\[301\]](#cite_note-307)^ The Youth Wing, which mounts changing exhibits and runs an extensive art education programme, is visited by 100,000 children a year. The museum has a large outdoor sculpture garden and includes the [Holyland Model of Jerusalem](/wiki/Holyland_Model_of_Jerusalem "Holyland Model of Jerusalem"), a scale-model of the city during the late [Second Temple period](/wiki/Second_Temple_period "Second Temple period").^[\[300\]](#cite_note-IMJ-306)^ The [Ticho House](/wiki/Ticho_House "Ticho House") in downtown Jerusalem houses the paintings of [Anna Ticho](/wiki/Anna_Ticho "Anna Ticho") and the Judaica collections of her husband, an ophthalmologist who opened Jerusalem's first eye clinic in this building in 1912.^[\[302\]](#cite_note-308)^{#cite_ref-308}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg/170px-Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg) [Jerusalem Biblical Zoo](/wiki/Jerusalem_Biblical_Zoo "Jerusalem Biblical Zoo")

Next to the Israel Museum is the [Bible Lands Museum](/wiki/Bible_Lands_Museum "Bible Lands Museum"), near [The National Campus for the Archaeology of Israel](/wiki/Israel_Antiquities_Authority#The_National_Campus_for_the_Archaeology_of_Israel "Israel Antiquities Authority"), which includes the [Israel Antiquities Authority](/wiki/Israel_Antiquities_Authority "Israel Antiquities Authority") offices. A World Bible Centre is planned to be built adjacent to [Mount Zion](/wiki/Mount_Zion "Mount Zion") at a site called the "Bible Hill". A planned [World Kabbalah Centre](/w/index.php?title=World_Kabbalah_Center&action=edit&redlink=1 "World Kabbalah Center (page does not exist)") is to be located on the nearby promenade, overlooking the Old City. The [Rockefeller Museum](/wiki/Rockefeller_Museum "Rockefeller Museum"), located in East Jerusalem, was the first archaeological museum in the Middle East. It was built in 1938 during the British Mandate.^[\[303\]](#cite_note-309)^^[\[304\]](#cite_note-310)^ In 2006, a 38 km (24 mi) [Jerusalem Trail](/wiki/Jerusalem_Trail "Jerusalem Trail") was opened, a hiking trail that goes to many cultural sites and [national parks](/wiki/National_parks "National parks") in and around Jerusalem. The [Jerusalem Biblical Zoo](/wiki/Jerusalem_Biblical_Zoo "Jerusalem Biblical Zoo") has ranked consistently as Israel's top tourist attraction for Israelis.^[\[305\]](#cite_note-311)^^[\[306\]](#cite_note-312)^ The national cemetery of Israel is located at the city's western edge, near the [Jerusalem Forest](/wiki/Jerusalem_Forest "Jerusalem Forest") on [Mount Herzl](/wiki/Mount_Herzl "Mount Herzl"). The western extension of Mount Herzl is the Mount of Remembrance, where the main Holocaust museum of Israel is located. [Yad Vashem](/wiki/Yad_Vashem "Yad Vashem"), Israel's national memorial to the victims of the [Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust"), houses the world's largest library of Holocaust-related information.^[\[307\]](#cite_note-313)^ It houses an estimated 100,000 books and articles. The complex contains a state-of-the-art museum that explores the genocide of the Jews through exhibits that focus on the personal stories of individuals and families killed in the Holocaust. An art gallery featuring the work of artists who perished is also present. Further, Yad Vashem commemorates the 1.5 million Jewish children murdered by the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazis "Nazis"), and honours the [Righteous among the Nations](/wiki/Righteous_among_the_Nations "Righteous among the Nations").^[\[308\]](#cite_note-YV-314)^{#cite_ref-YV_314-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/NationalLibraryofIsraelJan052023_-_2.jpg/220px-NationalLibraryofIsraelJan052023_-_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:NationalLibraryofIsraelJan052023_-_2.jpg) The new building of the [National Library of Israel](/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel "National Library of Israel")

The [Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Jerusalem_Symphony_Orchestra "Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra"), established in the 1940s,^[\[309\]](#cite_note-JSO-315)^ has appeared around the world.^[\[309\]](#cite_note-JSO-315)^ The [International Convention Centre](/wiki/International_Convention_Center_(Jerusalem) "International Convention Center (Jerusalem)") (*Binyanei HaUma* ) near the entrance to city houses the [Israel Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Israel Philharmonic Orchestra"). The Jerusalem Cinemateque, the [Gerard Behar Centre](/wiki/Gerard_Behar_Center "Gerard Behar Center") (formerly Beit Ha'Am) in downtown Jerusalem, the [Jerusalem Music Centre](/wiki/Jerusalem_Music_Centre "Jerusalem Music Centre") in [Yemin Moshe](/wiki/Yemin_Moshe "Yemin Moshe"),^[\[310\]](#cite_note-316)^ and the Targ Music Centre in [Ein Kerem](/wiki/Ein_Kerem "Ein Kerem") also present the arts. The [Israel Festival](/wiki/Israel_Festival "Israel Festival"), featuring indoor and outdoor performances by local and international singers, concerts, plays, and street theatre has been held annually since 1961, and Jerusalem has been the major organizer of this event. The [Jerusalem Theatre](/wiki/Jerusalem_Theater "Jerusalem Theater") in the [Talbiya](/wiki/Talbiya "Talbiya") neighbourhood hosts over 150 concerts a year, as well as theatre and dance companies and performing artists from overseas.^[\[311\]](#cite_note-317)^ The [Khan Theatre](/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Khan_Theatre "The Jerusalem Khan Theatre"), located in a caravanserai opposite the old Jerusalem train station, is the city's only [repertoire](/wiki/Repertory "Repertory") theatre.^[\[312\]](#cite_note-318)^ The station itself has become a venue for cultural events in recent years as the site of *Shav'ua Hasefer* (an annual week-long book fair) and outdoor music performances.^[\[313\]](#cite_note-319)^ The [Jerusalem Film Festival](/wiki/Jerusalem_Film_Festival "Jerusalem Film Festival") is held annually, screening Israeli and international films.^[\[314\]](#cite_note-filmfest-320)^ In 1974 the [Jerusalem Cinematheque](/wiki/Jerusalem_Cinematheque "Jerusalem Cinematheque") was founded. In 1981 it was moved to a new building on Hebron Road near the [Valley of Hinnom](/wiki/Valley_of_Hinnom "Valley of Hinnom") and the Old City.{#cite_ref-filmfest_320-0}

Jerusalem was declared the [Capital of Arab Culture](/wiki/2009_Capital_of_Arab_Culture "2009 Capital of Arab Culture") in 2009.^[\[315\]](#cite_note-ynetBan-321)^ Jerusalem is home to the [Palestinian National Theatre](/wiki/Palestinian_National_Theatre "Palestinian National Theatre"), which engages in cultural preservation as well as innovation, working to rekindle Palestinian interest in the arts.^[\[316\]](#cite_note-322)^ [The Edward Said National Conservatory of Music](/wiki/The_Edward_Said_National_Conservatory_of_Music "The Edward Said National Conservatory of Music") sponsors the Palestine Youth Orchestra^[\[317\]](#cite_note-323)^ which toured [Arab states of the Persian Gulf](/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf "Arab states of the Persian Gulf") and other Middle East countries in 2009.^[\[318\]](#cite_note-324)^ The [Islamic Museum](/wiki/Islamic_Museum "Islamic Museum") on the Temple Mount, established in 1923, houses many Islamic artifacts, from tiny [kohl](/wiki/Kohl_(cosmetics) "Kohl (cosmetics)") flasks and rare manuscripts to giant marble columns.^[\[319\]](#cite_note-325)^ Al-Hoash, established in 2004, is a gallery for the preservation of Palestinian art.^[\[320\]](#cite_note-alhoash-326)^ While Israel approves and financially supports some Arab cultural activities,^[\[321\]](#cite_note-327)^ Arab Capital of Culture events were banned because they were sponsored by the [Palestine National Authority](/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority "Palestinian National Authority").^[\[315\]](#cite_note-ynetBan-321)^ In 2009, a four-day culture festival was held in the [Beit 'Anan](/wiki/Beit_%27Anan "Beit 'Anan") suburb of Jerusalem, attended by more than 15,000 people^[\[322\]](#cite_note-328)^{#cite_ref-328}

[Palestinian cinema](/wiki/Palestinian_cinema "Palestinian cinema") is based in the city.^[\[323\]](#cite_note-329)^ Jerusalem has been location for "Jerusalem Arab Film Festival", for exhibiting [Palestinian films](/wiki/Cinema_of_Palestine "Cinema of Palestine").^[\[324\]](#cite_note-330)^ The city is home to numerous artists, singers, actors, actresses and filmmakers.^[\[325\]](#cite_note-331)^ Established in 1991, [Riwaq](/wiki/Riwaq_(organization) "Riwaq (organization)") have been working on various projects to restore cultural and historical sites across [Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine").^[\[326\]](#cite_note-332)^ Difficulties to operate in the [annexed areas of Palestinian Jerusalem](/wiki/Israeli_annexation_of_East_Jerusalem "Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem"), it have successfully worked across those neighborhoods, rural and suburban area and Jerusalem Mountains (*Jibal al-Quds* ), where the [Palestinian government](/wiki/Palestinian_government "Palestinian government") has control.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-333)^ So far, the organization have restored a number of sites across neighborhoods of [Kafr 'Aqab](/wiki/Kafr_%27Aqab "Kafr 'Aqab"), [Al Jib](/wiki/Al_Jib "Al Jib"), [Jaba](/wiki/Jaba%27,_Jerusalem "Jaba', Jerusalem") and [Qalandia](/wiki/Qalandia "Qalandia").^[\[328\]](#cite_note-:10-334)^ Those restored structures serves as local community centers, cultural sites and headquarters of several NGOs and cultural groups.^[\[328\]](#cite_note-:10-334)^ Yabous Cultural Center is the largest cultural center in the city, opened by Palestinian groups in 1997.^[\[329\]](#cite_note-335)^ [Edward Said National Conservatory of Music](/wiki/Edward_Said_National_Conservatory_of_Music "Edward Said National Conservatory of Music") have a branch in Jerusalem.{#cite_ref-335}

[Hadassah Medical Center](/wiki/Hadassah_Medical_Center "Hadassah Medical Center") and the Hebrew University have unveiled a "Tree of Peace" statue at the [Al Quds University School of Dental Medicine](/wiki/Al-Quds_University_Teaching_Hospital "Al-Quds University Teaching Hospital").^[\[330\]](#cite_note-336)^ The Museum on the Seam, which explores issues of coexistence through art, is situated on the road dividing eastern and western Jerusalem.^[\[331\]](#cite_note-seam-337)^ The Abraham Fund and the Jerusalem Intercultural Centre (JICC) promote joint Jewish-Palestinian cultural projects. The Jerusalem Centre for Middle Eastern Music and Dance^[\[332\]](#cite_note-338)^ is open to Arabs and Jews and offers workshops on Jewish-Arab dialogue through the arts.^[\[333\]](#cite_note-339)^ The Jewish-Arab Youth Orchestra performs both European classical and Middle Eastern music.^[\[334\]](#cite_note-340)^ In 2008, the [Tolerance Monument](/wiki/Tolerance_Monument "Tolerance Monument"), an outdoor sculpture by [Czesław Dźwigaj](/wiki/Czes%C5%82aw_D%C5%BAwigaj "Czesław Dźwigaj"), was erected on a hill between Jewish [Armon HaNetziv](/wiki/East_Talpiot "East Talpiot") and Arab [Jebl Mukaber](/wiki/Jabel_Mukaber "Jabel Mukaber") as a symbol of Jerusalem's quest for peace.^[\[335\]](#cite_note-341)^{#cite_ref-341}  

### Media {#Media}

The headquarters of the [Israel Broadcasting Authority](/wiki/Israel_Broadcasting_Authority "Israel Broadcasting Authority") and its successor [Israeli Public Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Israeli_Public_Broadcasting_Corporation "Israeli Public Broadcasting Corporation") are located in Jerusalem, as well as television and radio studios for [Channel 12](/wiki/Channel_12_(Israel) "Channel 12 (Israel)"), [Channel 13](/wiki/Channel_13_(Israel) "Channel 13 (Israel)"), and part of the radio studios of [BBC News](/wiki/BBC_News "BBC News"). *[The Jerusalem Post](/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Post "The Jerusalem Post")* and *[The Times of Israel](/wiki/The_Times_of_Israel "The Times of Israel")* are also headquartered in Jerusalem. Local newspapers include the Israeli *[Kol Ha'ir](/wiki/Kol_Ha%27ir "Kol Ha'ir")* and the Palestinian [*Jerusalem Times*](/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Times "The Jerusalem Times"). [God TV](/wiki/GOD_TV "GOD TV"), an international Christian television network, is also based in the city. [PYALARA](/wiki/Palestinian_Youth_Association_for_Leadership_and_Rights_Activation "Palestinian Youth Association for Leadership and Rights Activation"), an organisation based in Jerusalem, transformed [Jaba](/wiki/Jaba%27,_Jerusalem "Jaba', Jerusalem") into a digital hub, which is the Middle East's first digital village and is also home to first Media Interactive Learning Center in the Middle East.^[\[336\]](#cite_note-342)^{#cite_ref-342}  

### Sports {#Sports}

See also: [Beitar Jerusalem F.C.](/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C. "Beitar Jerusalem F.C."), [Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.](/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_B.C. "Hapoel Jerusalem B.C."), and [Jerusalem Marathon](/wiki/Jerusalem_Marathon "Jerusalem Marathon")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/TeddyStadiumJerusalem%D9%90Apr172023_03.jpg/220px-TeddyStadiumJerusalem%D9%90Apr172023_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:TeddyStadiumJerusalem%D9%90Apr172023_03.jpg) [Teddy Stadium](/wiki/Teddy_Stadium "Teddy Stadium"), [Malha](/wiki/Malha "Malha") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/JerusalemArenaApr172023_01.jpg/220px-JerusalemArenaApr172023_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:JerusalemArenaApr172023_01.jpg) [Pais Arena](/wiki/Pais_Arena "Pais Arena")

The two most popular sports are [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") (soccer) and basketball.^[\[337\]](#cite_note-343)^ [Beitar Jerusalem Football Club](/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C. "Beitar Jerusalem F.C.") is one of the most well known in Israel. Fans include political figures who often attend its games.^[\[338\]](#cite_note-344)^ Jerusalem's other major football team, and one of Beitar's top rivals, is [Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.](/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_F.C. "Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.") Whereas Beitar has been [Israel State Cup](/wiki/Israel_State_Cup "Israel State Cup") champion seven times,^[\[339\]](#cite_note-345)^ Hapoel has won the Cup only once. Beitar has won the top league six times, while Hapoel has never succeeded. Beitar plays in the more prestigious [Ligat HaAl](/wiki/Israeli_Premier_League "Israeli Premier League"), while Hapoel is in the second division [Liga Leumit](/wiki/Liga_Leumit "Liga Leumit"). Since its opening in 1992, [Teddy Stadium](/wiki/Teddy_Stadium "Teddy Stadium") has been Jerusalem's primary football stadium, with a capacity of 31,733^[\[340\]](#cite_note-346)^{#cite_ref-346}

The most popular Palestinian football club is [Jabal Al Mukaber](/wiki/Jabal_Al_Mukaber_(football_club) "Jabal Al Mukaber (football club)") (since 1976) which plays in West Bank Premier League. The club hails from Mount Scopus at Jerusalem, part of the [Asian Football Confederation](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation"), and plays at the [Faisal Al-Husseini International Stadium](/wiki/Faisal_Al-Husseini_International_Stadium "Faisal Al-Husseini International Stadium") at [Al-Ram](/wiki/Al-Ram "Al-Ram"), across the [West Bank Barrier](/wiki/West_Bank_Barrier "West Bank Barrier").^[\[341\]](#cite_note-pfa-347)^^[\[342\]](#cite_note-footwall-348)^{#cite_ref-footwall_348-0}

In basketball, [Hapoel Jerusalem](/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_B.C. "Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.") is one of the top teams in the [top division](/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_Super_League "Israeli Basketball Super League"). The club has won Israel's championship in 2015, the [State Cup](/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_State_Cup "Israeli Basketball State Cup") four times, and the [ULEB Cup](/wiki/EuroCup_Basketball "EuroCup Basketball") in 2004.^[\[343\]](#cite_note-349)^{#cite_ref-349}

The [Jerusalem Marathon](/wiki/Jerusalem_Marathon "Jerusalem Marathon"), established in 2011, is an international marathon race held annually in Jerusalem in the month of March. The full 42-kilometre race begins at the Knesset, passes through Mount Scopus and the Old City's Armenian Quarter, and concludes at Sacher Park. In 2012, the Jerusalem Marathon drew 15,000 runners, including 1,500 from fifty countries outside Israel.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-350)^^[\[345\]](#cite_note-351)^^[\[346\]](#cite_note-352)^^[\[347\]](#cite_note-353)^^[\[348\]](#cite_note-354)^{#cite_ref-354}

A popular non-competitive sports event is the [Jerusalem March](/wiki/Jerusalem_March "Jerusalem March"), held annually during the [Sukkot](/wiki/Sukkot "Sukkot") festival.

Notes {#Notes}
--------------

1. **[\^](#cite_ref-4)** The State of Palestine (according to the Basic Law of Palestine, Title One: Article 3) regards Jerusalem as its capital.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-BasicLawPal-T1A3-1)^ However, the documents of the [PLO](/wiki/PLO "PLO")'s Negotiations Affairs Department (NAD) often refer to [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem") (rather than the whole of Jerusalem) as a future capital, and sometimes as the current capital. One of its 2010 documents, described as "for discussion purposes only", says that Palestine has a "vision" for a future in which "East Jerusalem \[...\] shall be the capital of Palestine, and West Jerusalem shall be the capital of Israel."^[\[2\]](#cite_note-PLO-NAD-2010-2)^ One of its 2013 documents refers to "Palestine's capital, East Jerusalem", and states that "Occupied East Jerusalem is the natural socio-economic and political center for the future Palestinian state", while also stating that "Jerusalem has always been and remains the political, administrative and spiritual heart of Palestine" and that "The Palestinian acceptance of the 1967 border, which includes East Jerusalem, is a painful compromise".^[\[3\]](#cite_note-PLO-NAD-2013-3)^{#cite_ref-PLO-NAD-2013_3-0}
{#cite_note-4}

3. **[\^](#cite_ref-9)** Jerusalem is the capital under [Israeli law](/wiki/Jerusalem_Law "Jerusalem Law"). The presidential residence, government offices, supreme court and parliament ([Knesset](/wiki/Knesset "Knesset")) are there. The State of Palestine (according to the Basic Law of Palestine, Title One: Article 3) regards Jerusalem as its capital.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-BasicLawPal-T1A3-1)^ The UN and most countries do not recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, taking the position that the final status of Jerusalem is pending future negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Most countries maintain their embassies in [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv") and its suburbs or suburbs of Jerusalem, such as [Mevaseret Zion](/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion "Mevaseret Zion") (see ["Map of Israel"](https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf) (PDF). [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20200601135924/https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf) (PDF) from the original on 1 June 2020. Retrieved 28 June 2017. (319 KB)) See [Status of Jerusalem](/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem "Status of Jerusalem") for more information.{#cite_ref-BasicLawPal-T1A3_1-1}
{#cite_note-9}
4. **[\^](#cite_ref-19)** Statistics regarding the demographics of Jerusalem refer to the unified and expanded Israeli municipality, which includes the pre-1967 Israeli and [Jordanian](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan") municipalities as well as several additional [Palestinian](/wiki/Palestinians "Palestinians") villages and neighborhoods to the northeast. Some of the Palestinian villages and neighborhoods have been relinquished to the [West Bank](/wiki/West_Bank "West Bank") *de facto* by way of the [Israeli West Bank barrier](/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier "Israeli West Bank barrier"),^[\[15\]](#cite_note-laub2006-18)^ but their legal statuses have not been reverted.{#cite_ref-laub2006_18-0}
{#cite_note-19}
5. \^ [^***a***^](#cite_ref-bible-david_22-0) [^***b***^](#cite_ref-bible-david_22-1) Much of the information regarding King David's conquest of Jerusalem comes from [Biblical](/wiki/Bible "Bible") accounts, but some modern-day historians have begun to give them credit due to a 1993 excavation.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-21)^{#cite_ref-21}
{#cite_note-bible-david-22}
6. **[\^](#cite_ref-42)** [West Jerusalem](/wiki/West_Jerusalem "West Jerusalem") comprises approximately one third of the municipal area of Jerusalem, with [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem") comprising approximately two-thirds. On the annexation of East Jerusalem, Israel also incorporated an area of the West Bank into the Jerusalem municipal area which represented more than ten times the area of East Jerusalem under Jordanian rule.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-39)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-40)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-Benvenisti1976-41)^{#cite_ref-Benvenisti1976_41-0}
{#cite_note-42}

Because here, newly arcing across the familiar quadrilateral of Jerusalem, are four double labels in bold capitals. At top left *Haret En-Nassara* and, beneath it, *Christian Quarter* ; at bottom left *Haret El-Arman* and *Armenian Quarter* ; at bottom centre *Haret El-Yehud* and *Jews' Quarter* ; and at top right -- the big innovation, covering perhaps half the city -- *Haret El-Muslimin* and *Mohammedan Quarter*, had shown this before. Every map has shown it since. The idea, in 1841, of a Mohammedan (that is, Muslim) quarter of Jerusalem is bizarre. It's like a Catholic quarter of Rome. A Hindu quarter of Delhi. Nobody living there would conceive of the city in such a way. At that time, and for centuries before and decades after, Jerusalem was, if the term means anything at all, a Muslim city. Many people identified in other ways, but large numbers of Jerusalemites were Muslim and they lived all over the city. A Muslim quarter could only have been dreamt up by outsiders, searching for a handle on a place they barely understood, intent on asserting their own legitimacy among a hostile population, seeing what they wanted to see. [United Nations Security Council Resolution 478](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 478") (20 August 1980; 14--0, U.S. abstaining) declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem (see [Kellerman 1993](#CITEREFKellerman1993), p. 140). See [Status of Jerusalem](/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem "Status of Jerusalem") for more information.{#cite_note-105}

The international community has taken a critical view of both deportations and settlements as being contrary to international law. General Assembly resolutions have condemned the deportations since 1969, and have done so by overwhelming majorities in recent years. Likewise, they have consistently deplored the establishment of settlements, and have done so by overwhelming majorities throughout the period (since the end of 1976) of the rapid expansion in their numbers. The Security Council has also been critical of deportations and settlements; and other bodies have viewed them as an obstacle to peace, and illegal under international law... Although East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights have been brought directly under Israeli law, by acts that amount to annexation, both of these areas continue to be viewed by the international community as occupied, and their status as regards the applicability of international rules is in most respects identical to that of the West Bank and Gaza.{#cite_note-147}

179. **[\^](#cite_ref-Teller2_185-0)** Teller, Matthew (2022). [*Nine Quarters of Jerusalem: A New Biography of the Old City*](https://books.google.com/books?id=SgQ3EAAAQBAJ). [Profile Books](/wiki/Profile_Books "Profile Books"). p. Chapter 1. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-78283-904-0](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-78283-904-0 "Special:BookSources/978-1-78283-904-0"). [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20230609194835/https://books.google.com/books?id=SgQ3EAAAQBAJ) from the original on 9 June 2023. Retrieved 30 May 2023. But it may not have been Aldrich and Symonds. Below the frame of their map, printed in italic script, a single line notes that 'The Writing' had been added by 'the [Revd. G. Williams](/wiki/George_Williams_(priest) "George Williams (priest)")' and 'the Revd. Robert Willis'... Some sources suggest \[Williams\] arrived before [\[Michael\] Alexander](/wiki/Michael_Alexander_(bishop) "Michael Alexander (bishop)"), in 1841. If so, did he meet Aldrich and Symonds? We don't know. But Williams became their champion, defending them when the Haram inaccuracy came up and then publishing their work. The survey the two Royal Engineers did was not intended for commercial release (Aldrich had originally been sent to [Syria](/wiki/Syria_(region) "Syria (region)") under 'secret service'), and it was several years before their military plan of Jerusalem came to public attention, published first in 1845 by their senior officer Alderson in plain form, without most of the detail and labelling, and then in full in 1849, in the second edition of Williams's book The Holy City. Did Aldrich and/or Symonds invent the idea of four quarters in Jerusalem? It's possible, but they were military surveyors, not scholars. It seems more likely they spent their very short stay producing a usable street-plan for their superior officers, without necessarily getting wrapped up in details of names and places. The 1845 publication, shorn of street names, quarter labels and other detail, suggests that... Compounding his anachronisms, and perhaps with an urge to reproduce Roman urban design in this new context, Williams writes how two main streets, north-south and east-west, 'divide Jerusalem into four quarters.' Then the crucial line: 'The subdivisions of the streets and quarters are numerous, but unimportant.' Historians will, I hope, be able to delve more deeply into Williams's work, but for me, this is evidence enough. For almost two hundred years, virtually the entire world has accepted the ill-informed, dismissive judgementalism of a jejune Old Etonian missionary as representing enduring fact about the social make-up of Jerusalem. It's shameful... With Britain's increased standing in Palestine after 1840, and the growth of interest in biblical archaeology that was to become an obsession a few decades later, it was vital for the Protestant missionaries to establish boundaries in Jerusalem... Williams spread his ideas around. [Ernst Gustav Schultz](/w/index.php?title=Ernst_Gustav_Schultz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ernst Gustav Schultz (page does not exist)") \[[de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Gustav_Schultz "de:Ernst Gustav Schultz"); [he](https://he.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D7%90%D7%A8%D7%A0%D7%A1%D7%98_%D7%92%D7%95%D7%A1%D7%98%D7%91_%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9C%D7%A5 "he:ארנסט גוסטב שולץ")\], who came to Jerusalem in 1842 as Prussian vice-consul, writes in his 1845 book Jerusalem: *Eine Vorlesung* ('A Lecture'): 'It is with sincere gratitude I must mention that, on my arrival in Jerusalem, Mr Williams ... willingly alerted me to the important information that he \[and\] another young Anglican clergyman, Mr Rolands, had discovered about the topography of \[Jerusalem\].' Later come the lines: 'Let us now divide the city into quarters,' and, after mentioning Jews and Christians, 'All the rest of the city is the Mohammedan Quarter.' Included was [a map](/wiki/Kiepert_maps_of_Palestine_and_Jerusalem "Kiepert maps of Palestine and Jerusalem"), drawn by [Heinrich Kiepert](/wiki/Heinrich_Kiepert "Heinrich Kiepert"), that labelled the four quarters, mirroring Williams's treatment in *The Holy City*.{#cite_note-Teller2-185}
{#cite_note-Teller2-185}
